item.title: The Moguls Went to Davos—Then We Went Shopping
item.description:
A Tech Mogul’s Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style
Tackling global dilemmas is what the World Economic Forum does best, and keen observers of the happenings at Davos, Switzerland, can definitely glean a sense of where the world might be heading. It’s also not a bad place to pick up a sense of mogul-appropriate winter wear. “Dressing for Davos isn’t easy,” admitted Victoria Hitchcock, a Silicon Valley personal stylist, who helped a few attendees pack their bags for the conclave. “The elements make it a hard trip if you want to look lighthearted and effortless.” (Among her top pieces of advice? Multiple shoe options. “Your feet will get wet,” she said.) For the most part, the technorati and other corporate titans turned out for the occasion looking sharp. There was Accenture’s Julie Sweet in a powder-pink power suit and Yidu Tech founder Gong Yingying in a glossy, cinch-waist puffer jacket, which she partnered with elegant pearls—perfect for a daytime conference followed by a moonlit dinner at the Panorama Hotel. And of course, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang came kitted out in polished leather.
Jan 24, 2026

The Top 5

A Tech Mogul’s Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style

By Esther Achara

Tackling global dilemmas is what the World Economic Forum does best, and keen observers of the happenings at Davos, Switzerland, can definitely glean a sense of where the world might be heading. It’s also not a bad place to pick up a sense of mogul-appropriate winter wear.

“Dressing for Davos isn’t easy,” admitted Victoria Hitchcock, a Silicon Valley personal stylist, who helped a few attendees pack their bags for the conclave. “The elements make it a hard trip if you want to look lighthearted and effortless.” (Among her top pieces of advice? Multiple shoe options. “Your feet will get wet,” she said.)

For the most part, the technorati and other corporate titans turned out for the occasion looking sharp. There was Accenture’s Julie Sweet in a powder-pink power suit and Yidu Tech founder Gong Yingying in a glossy, cinch-waist puffer jacket, which she partnered with elegant pearls—perfect for a daytime conference followed by a moonlit dinner at the Panorama Hotel. And of course, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang came kitted out in polished leather.

item.title: Exclusive: Inside OpenAI’s Plans to Lure Big Business From Anthropic
item.description:
OpenAI Aims to Lure Businesses From Anthropic
Some of OpenAI’s most attention-grabbing efforts over the past year have involved products for consumers, from a social app to an AI-powered device it plans to announce later this year. Last week, though, the company’s CEO, Sam Altman, gathered Disney CEO Bob Iger and other corporate executives in San Francisco to deliver a message: OpenAI is serious about catering to business customers. Over a lavish multicourse dinner accompanied by fine wines, Altman told attendees OpenAI could be a one-stop shop for all their AI needs, from ChatGPT to its coding tool, Codex, to its models for automating workflows, said a person with knowledge of the company’s plans.
Jan 24, 2026

Exclusive

OpenAI Aims to Lure Businesses From Anthropic

By Kevin McLaughlin and Sri Muppidi

Some of OpenAI’s most attention-grabbing efforts over the past year have involved products for consumers, from a social app to an AI-powered device it plans to announce later this year. Last week, though, the company’s CEO, Sam Altman, gathered Disney CEO Bob Iger and other corporate executives in San Francisco to deliver a message: OpenAI is serious about catering to business customers.

Over a lavish multicourse dinner accompanied by fine wines, Altman told attendees OpenAI could be a one-stop shop for all their AI needs, from ChatGPT to its coding tool, Codex, to its models for automating workflows, said a person with knowledge of the company’s plans.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • OpenAI plans a new offering to business’ efforts to use AI
  • OpenAI aims to counter rival Anthropic’s strong traction with enterprise customers
  • Executives have been courting big clients in Davos, San Francisco

Legal AI giant Harvey acquires Hexus as competition heats up in legal tech

Article Summary:

  • • Legal AI startup Harvey has acquired Hexus, a toolmaker for product demos and guides, to enhance its enterprise AI offerings for in-house legal teams. Hexus founder Sakshi Pratap will lead an engineering team to accelerate Harvey’s growth.
  • • Harvey, valued at $8 billion, has raised $760 million in 2025, with backing from Andreessen Horowitz, Sequoia Capital, and others. It now serves over 1,000 clients, including a majority of the top 10 U.S. law firms.
  • • Harvey’s journey began with a cold email to OpenAI’s Sam Altman in 2022, leading to early funding and rapid adoption of GPT-powered tools to transform the legal industry.

Article Summary:

  • • Sam Altman is expected to visit India during the India AI Impact Summit 2026 in February, where global tech leaders like Sundar Pichai and Jensen Huang will gather. OpenAI plans to host closed-door meetings and an event in New Delhi to engage with industry executives and venture capitalists.
  • • India has become a key market for AI firms, with OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google expanding operations and partnerships in the country. OpenAI is focusing on enterprise adoption of ChatGPT while exploring infrastructure expansion despite challenges like power and water constraints.

Who’s behind AMI Labs, Yann LeCun’s ‘world model’ startup

Article Summary:

  • • AMI Labs, founded by AI pioneer Yann LeCun, focuses on creating "world models" to build AI systems capable of understanding the real world, emphasizing reliability, safety, and controllability. Applications include healthcare, robotics, automation, and industrial processes.
  • • The startup plans to license its technology for real-world applications while contributing to open AI research through publications and open-source initiatives. Unlike large language models, AMI’s approach prioritizes reasoning, planning, and persistent memory over generative AI.
  • • AMI Labs is reportedly raising funds at a $3.5 billion valuation, with potential investors including Cathay Innovation, Greycroft, and Hiro Capital. Its global presence spans Paris (HQ), New York, Montreal, and Singapore, solidifying Paris as a growing AI hub.
Microsoft gave FBI a set of BitLocker encryption keys to unlock suspects’ laptops: Reports

Article Summary:

  • • Microsoft provided the FBI with recovery keys to decrypt data on three laptops involved in a fraud investigation tied to the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program in Guam. BitLocker encryption, enabled by default on many Windows devices, relies on recovery keys stored in Microsoft's cloud.
  • • Microsoft disclosed that it receives an average of 20 requests per year from authorities for BitLocker recovery keys, raising concerns about user privacy and the potential for misuse if Microsoft's cloud infrastructure is compromised by hackers.
  • • Cryptography expert Matthew Green criticized Microsoft for its inability to secure critical customer keys, warning that breaches of such keys could pose serious risks if attackers gain physical access to encrypted devices.

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 24, 2026
Auto-compact not triggering on Claude.ai despite being marked as fixed
• Article: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/18866
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46736091
• Score: 185
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The auto-compact feature on Claude.ai (web and desktop) is malfunctioning, causing messages to bounce back to the input box or trigger "limit reached" errors. This disrupts workflows, especially during long conversations.
  • • Users report the feature has been broken since a major outage on January 14, despite Anthropic marking it as fixed on January 15. Some users are forced to manually compact or start new sessions frequently, leading to frustration.
  • • Anthropic has acknowledged the issue and is investigating, with intermittent fixes reported, but a full resolution remains pending.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • **Performance Degradation in Claude Opus 4.5**: Many users expressed frustration with perceived declines in the quality of the Claude Opus 4.5 model. Common complaints included failure to follow instructions, errors in workflows that previously worked, and inconsistent or buggy behavior.
  • • **A/B Testing and Model Changes**: Some commenters speculated that Anthropic might be conducting A/B testing or making changes to the model, such as quantization or new tokenization strategies, which could explain the inconsistencies.
  • • **Issues with Claude Code**: Specific problems with Claude Code were discussed, such as broken rollbacks, lack of checkpoints in the VS Code GUI, and general bugginess in both the terminal and GUI versions. Some users noted difficulties with the login process and support responsiveness.
  • • **Vibe Coding and AI-Generated Codebases**: Several comments criticized the reliance on AI-generated codebases, describing them as poorly maintained and riddled with bugs. This led to discussions about the challenges of fixing large AI-written codebases and whether LLMs are suitable for such tasks.
  • • **User Experience and Support**: Many commenters highlighted poor user experiences, including silent failures, rapid token consumption, and a lack of effective customer support. Some accused Anthropic of gaslighting users when issues were reported.
  • • **Speculation on Business Practices**: There was skepticism about Anthropic's business strategies, with some suggesting that model degradation might be intentional to cut costs or align with financial goals, especially with an IPO on the horizon.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreements**:
  • • Many users agreed that Claude Opus 4.5 has become less reliable and more error-prone compared to earlier iterations.
  • • There was consensus that Anthropic's support and communication with users are lacking.
  • • Commenters generally agreed that AI tools, while useful, still require significant oversight and are far from replacing human engineers.
  • • **Disagreements**:
  • • Some users attributed the issues to their own rising expectations or random noise, while others firmly believed the model had been "nerfed" or intentionally degraded.
  • • A few commenters shared positive experiences, claiming their workflows were still effective, contrasting with the majority's negative sentiment.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment of the discussion was predominantly negative, with frustration and dissatisfaction being the dominant emotions. Users were particularly critical of the perceived decline in quality, poor support, and lack of transparency from Anthropic.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • A commenter noted that A/B testing might explain the inconsistent performance, suggesting that high-usage users could be targeted for testing.
  • • Another user highlighted the challenges of fixing bugs in AI-written codebases, emphasizing the need for better testing and modularization.
  • • Some commenters speculated that the financial pressures of scaling and profitability might be driving decisions that negatively impact user experience.
  • • A recurring theme was the idea of "vibe coding," where rapid development and reliance on AI lead to unstable and poorly maintained software.
  • 5. **Conclusion**:
  • • The discussion reflects growing user frustration with Claude Opus 4.5 and Claude Code, particularly regarding reliability, usability, and support. While some users acknowledged the benefits of LLMs, the majority expressed concerns about their limitations and the broader implications of current business practices in the AI industry.
Nobody likes lag: How to make low-latency dev sandboxes
• Article: https://www.compyle.ai/blog/nobody-likes-lag/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46735139
• Score: 89
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Compyle revamped its architecture to eliminate lag in remote coding environments, reducing terminal roundtrip latency from over 200ms to just 14ms by cutting out socket servers and placing sandboxes closer to users.
  • • Key upgrades include a warm pool for instant sandbox startup (from 30s to 50ms) and multi-regional pools across the US, Europe, and Asia, ensuring users access the nearest data center for optimal speed.
  • • Leveraging fly.io's infrastructure and innovative proxying mechanisms like fly replay streamlined routing, reduced complexity, and significantly boosted performance.
  • #TechInnovation #CloudComputing #DeveloperTools

Discussion Highlights:

  • • **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • 1. **Cold Start Latency in Cloud Services**: Several commenters discussed the performance of Google Cloud Run and Cloud Functions v2 compared to AWS Lambda, particularly in terms of cold start latency. AWS Lambda's use of Firecracker was highlighted for achieving sub-second startup times, while GCP options were noted to have longer startup delays.
  • 2. **Sandboxing and Routing Optimization**: A recurring theme was the need for efficient sandboxing solutions, particularly in the context of coding agents and latency reduction. Commenters shared strategies like encoding routing logic into hostnames to eliminate database lookups and using tools like Pingora for improved connection lifecycle control.
  • 3. **Cost vs. Performance Trade-offs**: Several comments addressed the balance between optimizing latency and managing costs, such as shallow warm pools, memory snapshots, and multi-region setups. The economics of maintaining idle capacity were also discussed.
  • 4. **The Rise of Sandboxing Tools**: There was debate about the recent surge in sandbox-related tools and posts, attributed to the growing demand for coding agents and the need for "YOLO mode" execution. Some commenters questioned the necessity of SaaS sandboxes when local resources could suffice.
  • 5. **Developer Frustrations with Remote Infrastructure**: Frustrations were expressed about the complexity and inefficiency of modern development workflows, with some advocating for local development environments over cloud-based solutions.
  • 6. **Specific Tools and Recommendations**: Various tools like Fly.io's sprites.dev, Mosh, and Pingora were discussed, with mixed opinions on their readiness and applicability to different use cases.
  • • **Significant Agreements/Disagreements**:
  • • There was general agreement on the importance of reducing latency and optimizing sandboxing, but differing opinions on whether cloud-based or local solutions are more practical.
  • • Some commenters expressed skepticism about the necessity of complex cloud setups for development, while others emphasized the value of distributed infrastructure for specific use cases.
  • • The debate over SaaS sandboxes highlighted a divide between those who value their convenience and those who see them as unnecessary compared to leveraging local hardware.
  • • **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • Encoding routing logic into hostnames to eliminate database lookups was a notable optimization shared by a commenter.
  • • Fly.io's sprites.dev was mentioned as an emerging tool with innovative features like progressive checkpointing, though it was deemed immature for some use cases.
  • • A commenter highlighted the inefficiency of sending excessive network packets per keystroke, emphasizing the need for more streamlined approaches.
  • • **Overall Sentiment**:
  • The discussion was a mix of constructive technical insights and critical commentary. While many commenters shared practical solutions and recommendations, there was a notable undercurrent of frustration with the inefficiencies and perceived over-engineering of modern development workflows. The tone was largely analytical, with some humor and sarcasm interspersed.
  • • **Noteworthy Contributions**:
  • • The mention of Pingora and its advantages over NGINX for connection lifecycle control.
  • • The critique of Fly.io's sprites.dev for lacking certain features but being promising for new projects.
  • • The suggestion to reduce middleware and routing layers to improve latency, resonating with several participants.
What Will You Do When AI runs Out of Money and Disappear?
• Article: https://louwrentius.com/what-will-you-do-when-ai-will-run-out-of-money-and-disappear.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730995
• Score: 48
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Major AI services like ChatGPT and Claude are heavily subsidized, with no clear path to profitability due to exorbitant operational costs. Experts predict these services may shut down or become prohibitively expensive.
  • • Open-source models and smaller AI players could fill the gap, but they face the same cost challenges, making large-scale AI operations financially unviable without subsidies.
  • • Self-hosting AI systems is also cost-prohibitive, and rising demand for hardware could further inflate expenses. A potential scenario involves government intervention to subsidize AI services to maintain accessibility.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics of Discussion**:
  • • The cost and sustainability of AI, particularly the expenses related to inference versus training.
  • • The viability of self-hosting AI models and the associated hardware costs.
  • • The potential evolution of AI technology, hardware, and efficiency over time.
  • • Speculation about the AI industry's profitability and future business models.
  • • The potential impact of an AI market crash on hardware prices and accessibility.
  • 2. **Key Points**:
  • • There is debate about whether inference costs are heavily subsidized or genuinely profitable. Some commenters cite Sam Altman’s claim that OpenAI is profitable on inference, while others question whether current prices are propped up by investor capital.
  • • Open-source AI models and smaller providers offer significantly lower costs for inference compared to major players, suggesting AI could remain accessible even if larger companies struggle.
  • • Self-hosting AI is increasingly feasible, with some commenters sharing personal experiences of running models on consumer-grade or older hardware. This indicates that AI could become more decentralized and cost-effective over time.
  • • Hardware advancements and optimizations, such as inferencing-specific chips and kv cache, are expected to make AI more efficient and affordable in the future.
  • • There is skepticism about the long-term valuations of AI companies, with some predicting a market correction but maintaining that AI technology itself is here to stay.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • Many agree that AI is unlikely to disappear even if the current market bubble bursts, drawing parallels to the dot-com bubble.
  • • There is disagreement on the current and future costs of hosting AI, with some arguing that self-hosting is viable and others emphasizing the high upfront and operational costs.
  • • Commenters differ on whether AI will become cheaper or remain expensive, with some predicting hardware price drops after a potential market crash and others emphasizing the ongoing costs of running AI at scale.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment is mixed but leans towards cautious optimism. While some express concerns about the sustainability of current AI business models and costs, there is a shared belief that AI technology will continue to evolve and become more accessible over time.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • • The idea that AI is still in its early stages, likened to the "coach-built" phase of automobiles, with significant room for efficiency and cost improvements.
  • • The notion that AI’s value proposition may shift over time, with companies focusing on niche applications or reducing reliance on training new models.
  • • A humorous but critical observation that AI's profitability might ultimately rely on ads, encapsulated in the phrase "AGI = Ads Generate Income.
  • 6. **Miscellaneous Observations**:
  • • Some commenters express frustration with the current state of AI, particularly its use in customer service and its perceived impact on creativity.
  • • There is a sense of nostalgia and skepticism among older participants, with one commenter lamenting the replacement of natural talent by AI in creative fields.
Show HN: First Claude Code client for Ollama local models
• Article: https://github.com/21st-dev/1code
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46722285
• Score: 44
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The discussion revolves around the integration and functionality of Anthropic's Claude Code with local models, particularly through llama.cpp and related tools.
  • • Several commenters highlight that this capability has been available for months using llama.cpp, with some sharing specific configurations and troubleshooting tips.
  • • There is interest in proxies that can translate between OpenAI-style models and Anthropic endpoints, with some users sharing their experiences and challenges in finding reliable solutions.
  • • Hardware requirements for running large models like the 30B model are discussed, with a focus on VRAM needs and performance considerations.
  • 2. **Key Points and Insights**:
  • • Users note that llama.cpp already supports the Anthropic API, and configurations such as setting the `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` and other environment variables are key to making it work.
  • • One commenter shares a guide to using Claude Code with local models, highlighting a specific issue with telemetry pings that required disabling non-essential traffic.
  • • Proxies for bridging Anthropic and OpenAI-style models are discussed, but there is frustration over incomplete or unreliable implementations.
  • • Hardware discussions suggest that running 30B models requires at least 24GB of VRAM for decent performance, with some users sharing their setups and experiences.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that integrating Claude Code with local models has been possible for some time, but users differ on the ease of setup and reliability of certain tools.
  • • Some commenters express frustration with the complexity of configurations and the lack of fully functional proxies for specific use cases.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment is mixed, with users appreciating the availability of tools and guides but also expressing frustration over setup challenges, hardware requirements, and incomplete solutions.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • A user shares a detailed guide to using Claude Code with local models, which includes troubleshooting tips and specific configurations.
  • • Another user provides a workaround for bypassing onboarding issues with Claude Code by modifying a configuration file.
  • 6. **Additional Observations**:
  • • Some commenters point out that other tools, such as Goose and OpenCode, have also enabled similar functionality for some time.
  • • A GitHub link for further resources was shared, and a correction was made to a URL in the discussion.
Autodesk burns the village to feed AI and the Cloud – cuts 7% of workforce
• Article: https://blog.adafruit.com/2026/01/22/autodesk-burns-the-village-to-feed-ai-and-the-cloud-cuts-7-of-workforce/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46728385
• Score: 42
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion centers around widespread dissatisfaction with Autodesk, particularly its business practices and software offerings. Many commenters describe the company as monopolistic, anti-consumer, and focused on profit over product quality.
  • 2. Several commenters criticize Autodesk's dominance in architectural, CAD, and BIM software markets, noting that vendor lock-in forces users to rely on its products despite high costs and poor quality. Some compare Autodesk unfavorably to competitors like Blender and Houdini in the 3D graphics space, which are gaining traction due to community support and innovation.
  • 3. There is agreement that Autodesk's acquisition of Revit has contributed to its monopoly in architecture software, enabling it to charge high prices. Some express frustration with the lack of viable open-source alternatives that match Autodesk's feature set.
  • 4. A thread explores the relationship between Autodesk's practices and Wall Street's approval. Commenters explain that Wall Street prioritizes short-term profits, favoring cost-cutting and margin-raising strategies, even if they lead to "enshittification" of products. Vendor lock-in is identified as a key factor that sustains Autodesk's profitability despite user dissatisfaction.
  • 5. While most comments are critical, one commenter shares a positive experience with Autodesk's Fusion 360, citing its affordability and functionality for beginners. However, this perspective is overshadowed by broader concerns about the company's practices.
  • 6. Unique insights include efforts to revive open-source alternatives like LibreDWG and the observation that Wall Street's incentives often conflict with long-term product quality and customer satisfaction.
  • 7. Overall sentiment is overwhelmingly negative, with Autodesk portrayed as a company that prioritizes profits over users, leveraging monopolistic practices and vendor lock-in to maintain dominance.

item.title: Weekend: OpenAI’s Chaos Energy
item.description:
The Weekend
Welcome, Weekenders! In this newsletter: • The Big Read: How Greg and Anna Brockman became MAGA’s newest megadonors  • The Takeway: When a Davos trip presents a chance to test AI’s limits 
Jan 24, 2026
Supported by
Welcome, Weekenders! In this newsletter:
• The Big Read: How Greg and Anna Brockman became MAGA’s newest megadonors 
• The Takeway: When a Davos trip presents a chance to test AI’s limits 
• The Top 5: The moguls went to Davos—then we went shopping 
• Plus, Recommendations—our weekly pop culture picks: “Articles of Interest,” “I Deliver Parcels in Beijing” and “The Night Manager”
 
In its life so far, OpenAI has accomplished any number of feats, including the releases of ChatGPT, Dall-E and Sora. Those tools, which craft words, pictures and videos with AI, have catalyzed an unprecedented boom time.
Those breakthroughs cast a radiant glow on OpenAI, and steadily, it collected more money faster than any startup ever from everyone who matters in Silicon Valley—never mind that some of its products flout both copyright law and good taste in nearly equal measure. And never mind that OpenAI’s board once spontaneously fired (and quickly rehired) its wunderkind CEO, an event that internally has been rebranded as “The Blip.” (I kid you not—that’s according to our star AI reporter, Stephanie Palazzolo.) 
For the better part of three years, OpenAI enjoyed an enviable perception of itself. The startup’s rise seemed both predestined and inextinguishable. 
Recently, though, the grand narrative about OpenAI has slipped out of the company’s hands, and its continued dominance no longer seems assured. For a good moment, I found this turn of events surprising. Later, I had to laugh at myself for falling for an OpenAI ploy, which I’ve come to consider the company’s actual greatest achievement to date: In retrospect, it’s astounding that it managed to convince a lot of people of its invincibility while a pile of evidence mounted showing that it runs on a stream of chaotic energy. On a list of reliable fuels, such a power source would rank near Iranian-refined plutonium.
I detected a strong sense of that volatility as I edited this week’s Big Read, which is about OpenAI co-founder Greg Brockman and his wife, Anna. Mostly, the piece delves into their foray into MAGA land and national politics. And there alone, I sense a good amount of chaos: Brockman, apparently, hasn’t ever held any strong political beliefs, and the donations mostly seem like an opportunistic bid to win favor with President Donald Trump, a fella as swayable as a weathervane in gale-force wind. So who knows what Brockman’s money will actually get him and what exactly it may cost him in the long run?
Our story does a good job of filling in the rest of the picture around the couple. Some of those details I must’ve known at one point but have since forgotten, like the fact that OpenAI has 11 co-founders. Eleven! Think of that chaos. I have a group chat with my friends that’s about the same size, and often we’re lucky if we can reach consensus on whether to arrive for brunch at 12:30 or 1. God forbid we try to arrive together on a definition of what constitutes humanlike AI.
Most of those 11 have left: Brockman and just two other co-founders still remain at OpenAI. I totally get why the others decamped. Chaos can get tiring. I’m very used to making brunch plans for 12 and eventually sitting down at a table for four. As Brockman has stayed, he and OpenAI have weathered plenty of internal strife. In 2024, for example, OpenAI and Brockman agreed he should take a sabbatical; there’d been complaints about his workplace combativeness. Three months later, he returned—shortly after another key executive, Mira Murati, left to begin a rival AI startup, Thinking Machines Lab. Chaos! 
In the last few days, OpenAI has grasped to retake control of its story. Shortly, it plans to launch ads, which might offer the same type of energy jolt you get from a mouthful of 6-milligram Zyns, and it has installed a new leader to shape the products it will sell to businesses. Meanwhile on X, one executive was complaining about a “narrative violation”—a corporate dog whistle meant to suggest unfair media coverage—regarding the company’s recent growth figures.
Will OpenAI recapture its former status quo? I’d like to think we’ve seen enough stories like our Big Read to make us all at least a liiittle bit more skeptical. Then again, all those Sora videos have left reality feeling rather permanently warped. 
What else from this week…
• If even a portion of Jared Kushner’s master plan for redeveloping Gaza happens, I somehow anticipate writing future profiles of Kushner family heirs that attribute their wealth to Mediterranean-front condominiums. 
• Om Malik, intrepid chronicler of several past tech eras, casts a weary eye on the realities of today: “In a system tuned for speed, authority is ornamental.”
• Franken-milk, moon landings—and the 21 other reasons why Wired thinks this century already belongs to China. (According to The New York Times, Donald Trump’s speech at Davos might qualify as yet another.)
• Greenoaks Capital and Altimeter Capital are suing the South Korean government over its treatment of Coupang, a Korean e-commerce giant that counts both firms as investors. (Here’s more on what Greenoaks normally gets up to.) 
• AI’s effects across the labor market aren’t very clear at all. That said, it seems pretty indisputable that it has rapidly altered the hunt for the entry-level job.
• A new trailer for the fifth season of “For All Mankind” has dropped. Elsewhere in Hollywood, Riz Ahmed’s dark comedy series about an actor who tries to get cast as James Bond, “Bait,” may just be the most enjoyable piece of Bond content in years.
• America wants “to break up with the calorie,” the Times repo—and dammit, I’ve just crumbled a cookies-and-cream protein bar all over my keyboard. 
• Vintage watch collecting has gotten cool and vibey, says The Economist—and just a touch problematic for some buyers. “Really, we’re addicts,” one collector admits. “Just instead of being addicted to alcohol or cigarettes or drugs, we’re addicted to the chase of acquiring a new watch.”—Abram Brown

A message from Resource Advisor+

Why Smart Companies Are Consolidating Their Sustainability Software Stack

The tools aren't the problem. The fragmentation between them is. When energy data lives in one place, carbon in another, and supply chain in a third, you can't see the risk — you can only react to it. Resource Advisor+ unifies the stack with AI that actually understands your business.

Discover now.

Weekend’s Latest Stories

The Big Read 

How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors
I’ve already talked up this report from our Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo and Sylvia Varnham O’Regan quite a bit, so I will only add that it is a compelling reflection of what happens when Silicon Valley realizes Washington is up for sale like never before. 

The Takeaway

What AI Missed About My Davos Reporting Trip
Our Jessica Lessin, The Information’s founder and editor in chief, had a very busy past few days in Davos, Switzerland, the annual power conclave that attracts enough politicos and moguls to fill a mountainside of chalets. AI was the talk of that town this year, and as Jessica began thinking about everything she’d learned from cruising around those snowy corridors of power, she found an opportunity to experiment with a buzzy piece of AI: Anthropic’s Claude Cowork.

The Top Five

A Tech Mogul’s Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style
To do right by Davos, the masters of the universe go dressed to impress. Esther Achara, a returning contributor to Weekend and a veteran of places like Vogue and Glamour, has scrutinized what everyone had on and used it to inspire for some shoppable advice on what to buy this season. As Esther firmly instructs in her piece: Cold and chic can find a warm embrace. 
Abram Brown is the editor of The Information's Weekend section. You can reach him at abe@theinformation.com or find him on X.
 
Listening: “Articles of Interest”
Avery Trufelman, host of “Articles of Interest,” manages to pull off the type of cross-genre reporting vanishingly few journalists can actually do. “Articles of Interest” is ostensibly a podcast about clothes, but  really, it’s an incisive examination of business, culture, history and fashion, so even if you don’t know the essential difference between a blazer and a suit coat—check the jacket’s pockets—you’ll find the pod enlightening. The latest season, which is the show’s seventh, looks at how what the military wears has such deep connections with what we civvies typically choose. (I write this on a day on which I donned a vintage field jacket, a crisp white T-shirt and a denim work shirt.) It’s the type of show that quietly gets you to look around and notice details about everyday life that might’ve otherwise gone unnoticed.—Abram Brown
Reading: “I Deliver Parcels in Beijing” by Hu Anyan
Over 19 tumultuous years within China, Hu Anyan lived as a modern-day nomad, lurching from job to job—19 of them, in fact. Nominally, Hu had studied home-appliance repair and advertising design, but neither background helped him win long-lasting employment: Sometimes the jobs evaporated, and sometimes he would just quit and move on, choosing to exist on the edges of society within a rapidly modernizing China. 
After time as a gas station attendant and a baker’s helper, Hu sold women’s clothes and car accessories online, achieving only limited sales as he tried to understand the various strategies for operating on the country’s various e-commerce sites. (“Even with data, spending money is an art,” writes Hu. “It requires a certain technique, or else you risk it going down the drain.”) Later, he worked in a logistics warehouse and delivered packages. Somehow, Hu found time to read widely—everyone from Hemingway to Capote to Joyce—and to journal often. Some of those reflections became a viral blog post during the pandemic, and in 2023, he published “I Deliver Parcels in Beijing” in China, where it has been quite popular. A few months ago, he released an English translation.
These days, Hu’s native land often looms as an enigmatic bogeyman of a country in Western minds. Anyone after greater insight into the place would find “I Deliver Parcels in Beijing” enriching. (Consider it a fine double feature with Dan Wang’s “Breakneck,” a monograph on American and Chinese innovation, which I previously recommended.) With spare prose, Hu presents rich observations on the China around him, shedding some real light on the nation’s internet economy and his countrymen’s toilsome approach to their jobs. “Work for the sole purpose of making a living is a miserable prison,” he writes, “which is why very few people will confess that this is what they do.”—A.B.
Watching: “The Night Manager” 
Spies rarely age with enormous amounts of grace—at least when it comes to the fictional ones, though I expect it’s much the same for the real-life ones. The latest example is Jonathan Pine (Tom Hiddleston), titular protagonist of the BBC’s “The Night Manager,” which has its long-awaited second season streaming on Amazon Prime. Pine, a former soldier turned—yes—hotel manager turned reluctant MI6 recruit, is ridden by clenched-jaw anxiety and plagued by flashbacks to season one’s violent events. It worries his agency-appointed therapist. “You frighten me,” she tells him. (Yikes! Never what a person wants to hear from their shrink.) 
The debut season took its plot from the show’s John le Carré source novel, and in an original adventure for this latest outing, Pine finds himself trying to solve his dead boss’s (Douglas Hodge) murder and stymie the suave Teddy Dos Santos (Diego Calva), an arms dealer. The story has some ties to the previous season and makes sure to carry on the tradition of picking a pretty place—this time, it’s mountainous, sun-drenched Colombia—and filling it with plenty of attractive people. (Along with Hiddleston and Calva, former model Camila Morrone plays Roxana Bolaños, a shipping broker.) Safe to say, no one on television has looked as resplendent in linen since Tom Ripley ransacked Dickie’s closet.—A.B.

item.title: The New MAGA Megadonors: OpenAI's Greg Brockman and His Wife Anna
item.description:
How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors
In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI’s president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans posted pictures of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who’s become Trump’s AI and crypto czar. It wasn’t the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump’s orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump’s revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.
Jan 23, 2026

The Big Read

How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors

By Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo, and Sylvia Varnham O'Regan

In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI’s president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans posted pictures of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who’s become Trump’s AI and crypto czar.

It wasn’t the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump’s orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump’s revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.

item.title: Major Crypto Exchanges Are Racing to Offer U.S. Stocks
item.description:
Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere
Some of the world’s biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that’s beyond the reach of U.S. regulators. Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.
Jan 23, 2026

Exclusive

Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere

By Yueqi Yang

Some of the world’s biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that’s beyond the reach of U.S. regulators.

Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Overseas crypto exchanges offer U.S. stock tokens, bypassing U.S. regulations.
  • Tokenized stock market value reached $915 million, up 19% monthly.
  • NYSE and Nasdaq plan to offer stock tokens, seeking regulatory approval.

item.title: I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.
item.description:
How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Source Code

I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.

How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed

by Kieran Klaassen

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

The bug report was deceptively simple: A user noticed that their email signature formatting was off in Cora, our AI-powered email assistant. I asked Claude Code to investigate and fix it. By morning, the fix had touched 27 files, and more than 1,000 lines of code had changed. I didn’t write any of them.

A year ago, I would have spent my afternoon reading that code. Line by line, file by file, squinting at the migration that moved email_signature from one database table to another, Ctrl+F-ing for every instance of our feature flags.

This time, I spent 15 minutes making decisions, and the code shipped without a single bug.

Before AI, code review meant reading every line a teammate wrote. You checked for typos, logic errors, and style inconsistencies, the way an editor reviews a manuscript. Now my code reviews no longer involve reading code. And I’ve gotten better at catching problems because of it.

This is code review done the compound engineering way: Agents review in parallel, findings become decisions, and every correction teaches the system what to catch next time. The signature fix that touched 27 files? Thirteen specialized AI reviewers examined it simultaneously while I made dinner.

I’ll show you how I set it up, how it caught a critical bug I would have missed, and how you can start—even without custom tooling.

The death of manual code review

Reading code, even briefly, gave me a sense of the shape of things. I could feel when the codebase was getting too complicated. By letting go of manual review, I worried that I’d lose that clarity, and the architecture would wander off without me.

But I realized, too, that manual code reviews were no longer sustainable. When a developer writes 200 lines, their manager might spend 20 to 40 minutes reading it. The ratio of time spent writing code to reviewing it holds at 5:1 or 10:1—I can sit down with a cup of coffee, and the coffee will still be warm by the time I finish. AI has broken that ratio. The time it takes to generate code has collapsed, but the time it takes for a human to review code hasn’t. Something had to give.

The shift from manual review happened slowly. When Claude Code enacted a set of fixes, I’d ask it questions, then read the diff (the line-by-line comparison showing what had changed). When I was satisfied, I’d hold my breath and merge the changes into the main codebase.

Nothing broke. The code was fine. It turned out that asking Claude to explain its reasoning—what it changed, why, and what might break—caught more than my tired eyes scrolling through diffs.

After a while, that close read turned into a quick skim. The skim turned into a glance. Eventually I found that by the time I had asked my questions, I’d already hit “merge.”

I still understood how good the code was—that clarity just came in a different way. Instead of feeling the shape of the code by reading it, I felt it by interrogating Claude Code:

  1. “Walk me through what you changed and why.”
  2. “What assumptions did you make?”
  3. “What would break this?”
  4. “Why did you ignore the feedback from kieran-reviewer?”

That last one needs explaining. kieran-reviewer is an AI agent I built—a specialized reviewer trained on my code preferences. It knows, for instance, that I prefer simple queries over complex queries and clear code over clever code. It’s one of 13 reviewers that examine every pull request before I see it.

Why so many agents? No single reviewer, human or AI, catches everything in a 27-file change. A security expert spots authentication gaps but misses database issues. A performance specialist catches slow queries but ignores style drift. I needed specialists working in parallel, each focused on what they’re good at. Together, they catch what I might miss from a manual review.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

Using the compound engineering plugin

My system for code review is rolled up into the compound engineering plugin. It’s a set of files in your codebase that extend what Claude Code can do. Here’s how it works.

Slash commands are shortcuts you type in the terminal—like /workflows:review or /workflows:plan—that trigger workflows. Each workflow is a markdown file with instructions for what Claude should do when you invoke it.

Agents are specialized AI workers, each defined in its own markdown file with a persona and focus area.

For the email signature fix, I ran a single command: /workflows:review, which spun up every agent on its list at once:

  1. kieran-rails-reviewer checks my personal style preferences
  2. code-simplicity-reviewer hunts for over-engineering
  3. data-integrity-guardian validates database changes during migrations (when the structure of your database changes)
  4. security-sentinel checks for authentication bypasses
  5. Plus nine more, each with a specific focus

Ten minutes later, they returned with findings ranked by priority.

From findings to decisions

The agents produce findings. But a list of issues isn’t useful—I need to know what to do about them. So I run the next command: /triage

Triage takes all 13 reviewers’ findings, ranks them by severity, and walks me through each one. It presents every finding in the same way: Here’s the problem, here’s why it matters, now what do you want to do?


I can accept the recommendation (and the system creates a task to fix it), skip it (it’s not worth addressing), or provide specific instructions.

The signature fix surfaced three findings. The first was critical: The code had moved where we store a user setting, but one file still looked for it in the old location. If I’d shipped this, every user who tried to generate a draft response would have hit an error. The fix itself is trivial—point the code at the new location—but I never would have caught it scrolling through diffs.

The second was cleanup. A chunk of unused code, left over from an earlier approach. It wasn’t broken, but it was confusing. On the chance that someone did read the code in the future, they would wonder what it was for. I approved this change too.

The third was a nitpick—a minor redundancy, technically true but harmless. I skipped it. I’ll clean it up next time I’m in that file.

I got three findings and made three decisions in less than two minutes.

The critical finding alone justified the review. I never would have caught a mismatched reference on line 31 while scrolling through 1,000 lines at 6 p.m. The agents caught it in seconds.

The fix is never the last fix

The signature fix should have been simple. I’d make one change and be done. But sometimes when you fix a piece of code, you end up breaking another. This is just as true with human developers as with coding agents.

In our case, the first version fixed the signature formatting in Gmail, but it broke the plain text version of emails. Some email apps don’t display styled text, and now those users saw raw formatting codes instead of readable text.

So we fixed that. But the fix for plain text created extra blank lines for users who didn’t have signatures at all.

So I fixed that too. Then we discovered that when you reply to a heavily-styled marketing email, our formatting rules were leaking into the quoted text. Users saw gibberish like #outlook a { padding: 0; } in their message body.

I fixed that. Next we found that Cora was now appending your email signature after each suggested draft of an email, instead of just once at the very end. If you generated three options, you’d get three signatures. Which called for another fix.

Ten versions of the code. Four bugs we introduced while fixing the original. Hence the 27 files and thousand lines of code. Again, this is a normal part of any development process, human or AI. The difference is that here, we can codify our learnings to make sure we don’t make the same mistake next time.

The 50/50 rule

I spent 15 minutes fixing those bugs. Then I spent another 15 minutes making sure I’d never see them again.

After the signature mess, we created a document called refactor-email-content-rendering.md. It lives in our codebase, and it captures everything we learned:

  1. A chart showing every combination of user settings and what should happen in each case, so there would be no more guessing.
  2. A simple rule about which part of the system handles formatting: “The background process sends styled text. The Gmail connector never converts formats.”
  3. The exact format Gmail expects for signatures, pulled from actual emails we tested—not what we assumed, but what we verified.

That document is now part of the project. The next time anyone touches email rendering—whether that’s me, a teammate, or Claude—the AI reads it first.

In my first weeks using this workflow, Claude presented me with approaches that weren’t necessarily wrong, but didn’t reflect my preferences. What I consider “over-engineered,” another engineer might call “robust.” What I see as a missed pattern, someone else might not use at all. Three months and 50-plus reviews in, Claude’s plans largely reflect how I’d approach problems myself.

Better AI models make everyone’s output better. But your system gets better because you’re accumulating your own team’s knowledge. Your agents learn your preferences, and your review process reveals your blind spots. That’s where compounding happens.

So follow the 50/50 rule: Spend half your time reviewing output, half ensuring the lesson sticks.

Rethink reviews

Most engineers assume they need to read everything. That assumption made sense when humans wrote all the code. But it doesn’t anymore.

I shipped the email signature fix without reading most of the code. I reviewed findings and made decisions. I looked at screenshots in Gmail. But did I read the implementation details of how we extract email content? No. Did I trace through how the database change handles edge cases? No.

Yet the feature works. Users get properly formatted signatures. The tests—checks I write alongside every feature to verify the code behaves correctly—all pass. The screenshots look right. It took some time to let go of manual code reviews, but the results speak for themselves.

The trade I’ve made is that I won’t read every line, but a part of the time I would spend reading code now goes toward making the system smarter. I’m adding test cases for marketing emails stuffed with weird formatting. I’m capturing “when you change where data lives, check every file that reads it” as a rule the agents enforce automatically. This way, the next person who touches this code—human or AI—doesn’t repeat my mistakes.

If you don’t have the compound engineering plugin yet, start with three questions. Before you approve any AI-generated output—code, documents, or strategy decks—ask the AI:

  1. What was the hardest decision you made here?
  2. What alternatives did you reject, and why?
  3. What are you least confident about?

That conversation, which takes two minutes, surfaces what a 30-minute unfocused manual check would have missed. The AI knows where the tricky parts are. It just doesn’t volunteer them unless you ask.

Then apply the 50/50 rule. Spend half of your time fixing the immediate problem and half documenting it, making sure the problem never comes back.

The 27 files involved in rendering an email signature are waiting for the next feature. I’m still not going to read them all. But when I’m done, the system will know more than it did when I started.

Kieran Klaassen is the general manager of Cora, Every’s email product. Follow him on X at @kieranklaassen or on LinkedIn.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

We build AI tools for readers like you. Write brilliantly with Spiral. Organize files automatically with Sparkle. Deliver yourself from email with Cora. Dictate effortlessly with Monologue.

We also do AI training, adoption, and innovation for companies. Work with us to bring AI into your organization.

item.title: The math on AI agents doesn’t add up
item.description:
PLUS: What hallucinations reveal about the future of automation.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

■ In this week’s Backchannel: A research paper suggests AI agents are mathematically doomed to fail. The industry doesn’t agree.

 

Agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time

The big AI companies promised us that 2025 would be “the year of the AI agents.” It turned out to be the year of talking about AI agents, and kicking the can for that transformational moment to 2026 or maybe later. But what if the answer to the question “When will our lives be fully automated by generative AI robots that perform our tasks for us and basically run the world?” is, like that New Yorker cartoon, “How about never?”

That was basically the message of a paper published without much fanfare some months ago, smack in the middle of the overhyped year of “agentic AI.” Entitled “Hallucination Stations: On Some Basic Limitations of Transformer-Based Language Models,” it purports to mathematically show that “LLMs are incapable of carrying out computational and agentic tasks beyond a certain complexity.” Though the science is beyond me, the authors—a former SAP CTO who studied AI under one of the field’s founding intellects, John McCarthy; and his teenage prodigy son—punctured the vision of agentic paradise with the certainty of mathematics. Even reasoning models that go beyond the pure word-prediction process of LLMs, they say, won’t fix the problem.

“There is no way they can be reliable,” Vishal Sikka, the dad, tells me. After a career that, in addition to SAP, included a stint as Infosys CEO and an Oracle board member, he currently heads an AI services startup called Vianai. “So we should forget about AI agents running nuclear power plants?” I ask. “Exactly,” he says. Maybe you can get it to file some papers or something to save time, but you might have to resign yourself to some mistakes.

The AI industry begs to differ. For one thing, a big success in agent AI has been coding, which took off last year. Just this week at Davos, Google’s Nobel-winning head of AI, Demis Hassabis, reported breakthroughs in minimizing hallucinations, and hyperscalers and startups alike are pushing the agent narrative. Now they have some backup. A startup called Harmonic is reporting a breakthrough in AI coding that also hinges on mathematics—and tops benchmarks on reliability.

Harmonic, which was cofounded by Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and Tudor Achim, a Stanford-trained mathematician, claims this recent improvement to its product called Aristotle (no hubris there!) is an indication that there are ways to guarantee the trustworthiness of AI systems. “Are we doomed to be in a world where AI just generates slop and humans can't really check it? That would be a crazy world,” says Achim. Harmonic’s solution is to use formal methods of mathematical reasoning to verify an LLM’s output. Specifically, it encodes outputs in the Lean programming language, which is known for its ability to verify the coding. To be sure, Harmonic’s focus to date has been narrow—its key mission is the pursuit of “mathematical superintelligence,” and coding is a somewhat organic extension. Things like history essays—which can’t be mathematically verified—are beyond its boundaries. For now.

Nonetheless, Achim doesn’t seem to think that reliable agentic behavior is as much an issue as some critics believe. “I would say that most models at this point have the level of pure intelligence required to reason through booking a travel itinerary,” he says.

Both sides are right—or maybe even on the same side. On one hand, everyone agrees that hallucinations will continue to be a vexing reality. In a paper published last September, OpenAI scientists wrote, “Despite significant progress, hallucinations continue to plague the field, and are still present in the latest models.” They proved that unhappy claim by asking three models, including ChatGPT, to provide the title of the lead author’s dissertation. All three made up fake titles and all misreported the year of publication. In a blog about the paper, OpenAI glumly stated that in AI models, “accuracy will never reach 100 percent.”

Right now, those inaccuracies are serious enough to discourage the wide adoption of agents in the corporate world. “The value has not been delivered,” says Himanshu Tyagi, cofounder of an open source AI company called Sentient. He points out that dealing with hallucinations can disrupt an entire work flow, negating much of the value of an agent.

Yet the big AI powers and many startups believe these inaccuracies can be dealt with. The key to coexisting with hallucinations, they say, is creating guardrails that filter out the imaginative bullshit that LLMs love to produce. Even Sikka thinks that this is a probable outcome. “Our paper is saying that a pure LLM has this inherent limitation—but at the same time it is true that you can build components around LLMs that overcome those limitations,” he says.

Achim, the mathematical verification guy, agrees that hallucinations will always be around—but considers this a feature, not a bug. “I think hallucinations are intrinsic to LLMs and also necessary for going beyond human intelligence,” he says. “The way that systems learn is by hallucinating something. It’s often wrong, but sometimes it's something that no human has ever thought before.”

The bottom line is that like generative AI itself, agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time. There may not be a specific annum that will be looked back upon as “the year of the agent.” But hallucinations or not, every year from now on is going to be “the year of more agents,” as the delta between guardrails and hallucinations narrows. The industry has too much at stake not to make this happen. The tasks that agents perform will always require some degree of verification—and of course people will get sloppy and we’ll suffer small and large disasters—but eventually agents will match or surpass the reliability of human beings, while being faster and cheaper.

At that point, some bigger questions arise. One person I contacted to discuss the hallucination paper was computer pioneer Alan Kay, who is friendly with Sikka. His view is that “their argument was posed well enough to get comments from real computational theorists.” (A statement reminiscent of his 1984 take on the Macintosh as “the first personal computer good enough to be criticized.”) But ultimately, he says, the mathematical question is beside the point. Instead, he suggests people consider the issue in light of Marshall McLuhan’s famous “Medium is the message” dictum. “Don’t ask whether something is good or bad, right or wrong,” he paraphrases. “Find out what is going on.”

Here’s what’s going on: We may well be on the cusp of a massive automation of human cognitive activity. It’s an open question whether this will improve the quality of our work and our lives. I suspect that the ultimate assessment of that will not be mathematically verifiable.

Time Travel

I was heartened that Tudor Achim spoke well of hallucinations, because two years ago I wrote “In Defense of AI Hallucinations,” a piece that embraced the possibility that AI would never rid itself of its troublesome inaccuracies. Like Achim, I celebrated the creative spirit of AI confabulation. But I also conjectured that as long as chatbots got stuff wrong, we wouldn’t let them take over the world. I’m not so sure about the last part anymore.

Santosh Vempala, a computer science professor at Georgia Tech, has also studied hallucinations. “A language model is just a probabilistic model of the world,” he says, not a truthful mirror of reality. Vempala explains that an LLM’s answer strives for a general calibration with the real world—as represented in its training data—which is “a weak version of accuracy.” His research, published with OpenAI’s Adam Kalai, found that hallucinations are unavoidable for facts that can’t be verified using the information in a model’s training data.

That’s the science/math of AI hallucinations, but they’re also notable for the experience they can elicit in humans. At times, these generative fabrications can seem more plausible than actual facts, which are often astonishingly bizarre and unsatisfying. How often do you hear something described as so strange that no screenwriter would dare script it in a movie? These days, all the time! Hallucinations can seduce us by appearing to ground us to a world less jarring than the actual one we live in. What’s more, I find it telling to note just which details the bots tend to concoct. In their desperate attempt to fill in the blanks of a satisfying narrative, they gravitate toward the most statistically likely version of reality as represented in their internet-scale training data, which can be a truth in itself. I liken it to a fiction writer penning a novel inspired by real events. A good author will veer from what actually happened to an imagined scenario that reveals a deeper truth, striving to create something more real than reality.

Ask Me One Question

Alexandra asks, “How do tech journalists stay curious without getting cynical?"

Thanks for the question, Alexandra. It’s helpful that you gave a clue as to what you meant by sharing that you are recovering from tech burnout and are worried about returning to that world “without falling back into the toxic parts.” So what you are saying is that some of the unattractive aspects of techland—selfish oligarchs, enshittified products, and the pursuit of progress without sufficient regard for what benefits society—can nullify what’s truly exciting about the field.

I can’t speak for all tech journalists, but what keeps me from being cynical is a perpetual fascination with the technology itself and the people who lend their creativity and acumen to building breakthrough products and making cutting-edge discoveries. For instance, I found that writing the backstory of the invention of AI transformers was inspiring, fun, and instructive.

And if some of those people turn to the dark side? Hey, that’s interesting too. Instead of fomenting cynicism, bad behavior on the part of powerful tech people calls for the scrutiny that journalists can and should exercise. Identifying the flaws in our world doesn’t make us cynical—beaming sunshine in dark corners is actually a hopeful act, urging people to do better. Even if fanboys rip us on social media for our work.

Quote of the Week

“[AI] may go too fast for society … Should you do it all at once? No. You will have civil unrest. So phase it in.”

—JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, speaking at Davos in favor of hitting the brakes on AI.

What did you think about today's newsletter? Let me know by emailing me at backchannel@wired.com

In Other News

  • We Are Witnessing the Self-Immolation of a Superpower With Donald Trump’s actions in Greenland, Minneapolis, and Venezuela, a foreign enemy could not invent a better chain of events to wreck the standing of the United States.
  • Chinese EV Batteries Are Eating the World China’s lithium batteries aren’t always “made in China.” Companies like BYD and CATL are building factories on nearly every continent.
  • Your First Humanoid Robot Coworker Will Probably Be Chinese Explosive acceleration, limited dexterity, eyes in the back of its head. What could possibly go wrong?

Sign Up to Our Other Subscriber Newsletters

Made in China

A clear-eyed view of the tech news coming out of China by Zeyi Yang and Louise Matsakis
Sign up

AI Lab

Resident AI expert Will Knight takes you to the furthest edges of this fast-changing field
Sign up

 

MORE FROM WIRED.COM

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 23, 2026
I was banned from Claude for scaffolding a Claude.md file?
• Article: https://hugodaniel.com/posts/claude-code-banned-me/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46723384
• Score: 616
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A developer using Anthropic's Claude AI for personal coding projects faced an account ban after automating prompts resembling system instructions, triggering moderation heuristics. The ban occurred without warning or explanation, highlighting the opaque nature of AI moderation systems.
  • • The developer's project involved running two Claude instances to iterate on scaffolding tools, but the process was flagged as a violation, possibly due to prompt injection concerns. The incident underscores challenges in using AI tools for advanced automation.
  • • Following the ban, the developer received a refund but no communication or support from Anthropic. The experience raises concerns about AI safety protocols prioritizing extreme caution over user engagement and accuracy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • **Service Reliability and Customer Support**: Many commenters shared frustrations with Anthropic's Claude service becoming unreliable, with issues such as flakiness, failed prompts, and unresponsiveness. A recurring theme was the lack of adequate customer support, which often consists of automated responses or an AI bot, with human escalation being rare or ineffective.
  • • **Account Bans and Lack of Transparency**: Several users reported being banned from Claude without clear explanations or recourse, sometimes after seemingly innocuous actions like using a VPN or submitting certain prompts. The lack of transparency in the banning process and appeals system was widely criticized.
  • • **Prompt Injection and Automation Concerns**: The discussion included speculation about bans being triggered by activities perceived as prompt injection or automation misuse, such as using Claude to modify its own behavior or scaffolding projects.
  • • **Alternatives to Claude**: Commenters debated other LLMs like ChatGPT, Gemini, and open-source models such as GLM, Mistral, and locally hosted solutions. Some expressed preference for open-source models to avoid corporate control and censorship.
  • • **Ethical and Systemic Issues**: The conversation touched on broader concerns about corporate control over AI tools, lack of accountability, and the implications of centralized AI systems on users' freedom and livelihoods.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: There was widespread consensus that Anthropic's customer support and transparency need significant improvement. Many commenters agreed that the lack of human support and unclear banning policies create a poor user experience.
  • • **Disagreement**: Opinions varied on the viability of alternatives to Claude. Some praised open-source models for independence, while others argued they lag behind proprietary models in quality and reliability. There was also debate over whether Anthropic's bans were justified or overly harsh.
  • • **Mixed Sentiments on AI Moderation**: While some supported strict moderation for safety, others criticized the over-reliance on automated systems and the lack of human oversight.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment was predominantly negative, with many users expressing frustration, disappointment, and distrust toward Anthropic's handling of Claude's reliability and support issues. Some commenters were optimistic about alternatives, while others were skeptical of their capabilities.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • **Local Models as a Solution**: Several commenters advocated for running local LLMs to avoid corporate restrictions and bans, emphasizing the importance of decentralization in AI.
  • • **Anthropic's Strategic Risk**: One commenter highlighted the potential damage to Anthropic's reputation if it doesn't trust its own AI for customer support, questioning why corporate clients should rely on Claude.
  • • **Broader Implications**: Commenters discussed the risks of centralized AI tools potentially barring users from industries or workflows, likening it to monopolistic control.
  • 5. **Recurring Issues**:
  • • **Token Usage and Costs**: Users reported dissatisfaction with unclear token limits and pricing, particularly for high-cost plans like Claude Max.
  • • **Automation and Prompt Injection**: Many commenters speculated that Anthropic's automated systems flagged benign actions as malicious, leading to bans.
  • • **Calls for Regulation**: Some commenters advocated for legal frameworks to prevent arbitrary bans and ensure accountability in AI services.
  • 6. **Notable Comments**:
  • • A commenter highlighted the chilling effect of Anthropic's banning practices on developers, discouraging investment in Claude-specific tools.
  • • Another user suggested prompt injection techniques could be exploited maliciously to ban organizations from AI tools.
  • • Discussions on open-source models like Mistral and GLM provided valuable insights into alternatives to proprietary LLMs.
  • In summary, the discussion underscored dissatisfaction with Anthropic's service reliability, customer support, and banning policies, while exploring alternatives and raising broader concerns about corporate control in AI.
Proton Spam and the AI Consent Problem
• Article: https://dbushell.com/2026/01/22/proton-spam/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46729368
• Score: 290
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Proton sent an email promoting its AI feature, Lumo, to a user who had explicitly opted out of Lumo-related communications, raising concerns about privacy and consent. The email was labeled as part of the "Proton for Business" newsletter, which the user disputes as misleading.
  • • The incident highlights broader issues within the AI industry, where companies often disregard user preferences and consent, pushing AI into products and services without explicit approval. This trend is criticized for undermining trust and violating ethical standards.
  • • The user calls out Proton's handling of the situation, emphasizing the growing problem of non-consent in tech, especially within the AI sector, which frequently sidesteps privacy laws and user autonomy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics of Discussion**:
  • • **Proton's Marketing Practices**: Many commenters criticized Proton's intrusive marketing emails, particularly around their AI product "Lumo." Users expressed frustration over receiving promotional emails despite opting out, with some suggesting this behavior undermines trust in the company.
  • • **AI and Consent**: The broader issue of AI being forcefully integrated into products and services without user consent was heavily discussed. Commenters noted that AI marketing often disregards user preferences, reflecting a trend of non-consensual implementation across the tech industry.
  • • **Comparison to Competitors**: Several commenters highlighted their dissatisfaction with Proton's overall suite of products, including email and VPN services, and shared positive experiences with alternatives like Fastmail and Tutanota.
  • • **Ethics and Accountability in Tech**: Commenters debated the ethical implications of marketing practices and the lack of consumer protection in the tech industry, pointing out that GDPR enforcement is limited outside of Europe.
  • • **Broader Tech Industry Trends**: Some commenters linked Proton's behavior to a larger trend of "enshittification," where companies prioritize profit over user experience and trust as they scale.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: Many commenters agreed that Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, are problematic and erode trust. There was consensus that non-consensual marketing emails are unethical and frustrating.
  • • **Disagreement**: While most criticized Proton, a few defended the company, arguing that the issue might stem from technical errors or misclassification rather than malice. Others felt the complaints were exaggerated and suggested unsubscribing was a simple solution.
  • • **AI-Specific Criticism**: Some commenters believed the issue is specific to AI hype and marketing, while others argued this behavior is typical of marketing teams in general, regardless of the product being promoted.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was largely negative, with commenters expressing dissatisfaction with Proton's marketing practices and broader trends in the tech industry. Frustration and distrust were common sentiments, especially regarding AI-related marketing and lack of respect for user preferences.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters shared personal experiences with Proton and other companies, highlighting issues like slow product development, poor customer support, and misleading marketing practices.
  • • A commenter provided a detailed perspective on how internal conflicts between support and marketing teams might lead to such incidents, offering insight into corporate dynamics.
  • • Comparisons to competitors like Fastmail and Tutanota revealed that users prioritize simplicity, reliability, and trust in their choice of email providers.
  • 5. **Key Takeaways**:
  • • Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, have led to significant user frustration and loss of trust.
  • • The tech industry's disregard for user consent in marketing and product integration is a widespread issue, with AI being a focal point.
  • • Many users are considering or have already switched to competitors due to dissatisfaction with Proton's products and practices.
  • • Ethical concerns and lack of accountability in tech marketing were recurring themes in the discussion.
