Article Summary:

  • • University of Alaska Fairbanks student Graham Granger protested AI-generated art by tearing and eating pieces of an exhibit, criticizing AI for undermining the creative process and relying on other artists' work without consent.
  • • Granger views AI as a valuable tool but believes it has no place in art, arguing that the lack of human effort and inability to process criticism devalues the art form and harms genuine artists.
  • • The incident, initially intended to spark campus-wide discussion, gained international attention, with Granger standing by his actions despite facing legal consequences.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around an incident where an individual ate an AI-generated art exhibit as a form of protest, sparking debates about the validity of AI art, artistic expression, and the ethics of such protests.
  • 2. **Themes and Points of Discussion**:
  • • **Protest and Impact**: Some commenters debated the effectiveness of the protest, with comparisons made to other acts of defiance, such as slashing oil truck tires. Opinions varied on whether targeting AI art was the right approach, with suggestions that companies like OpenAI or MidJourney might be more appropriate targets.
  • • **AI Art as a Medium**: There was significant discussion about the artistic value of AI-generated works. Some criticized AI art as low-effort and lacking in value compared to traditional art, while others acknowledged its potential to explore new creative ideas, such as "AI psychosis" and identity formation.
  • • **Artistic Impulses**: Several commenters reflected on the impulsive nature of the act, with some defending impulsivity as part of artistic expression and others dismissing it as misguided or unnecessary.
  • • **Legal and Ethical Considerations**: The conversation touched on the legal consequences of the protest, with discussions about pressing charges and the role of victims in prosecution. Some questioned the necessity of pursuing legal action for such a minor incident.
  • • **Cultural Context**: Comparisons were made to historical protests against new technologies in art, such as the backlash against mass-produced color printers. This led to broader reflections on how society values art and the artist's role in its creation.
  • 3. **Disagreements**:
  • • **Value of AI Art**: Opinions were divided on whether AI-generated art should be considered legitimate. Critics dismissed it as lacking artistic merit, while others argued that it is a valid medium deserving of exploration.
  • • **Protest Justification**: Some supported the protest as a form of direct action, while others saw it as counterproductive or ineffective in achieving meaningful change.
  • • **Sentiment Toward AI**: While some commenters expressed frustration and negativity toward AI's role in art, others called for a more informed understanding of the technology and its potential.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was mixed, with a blend of humor, skepticism, and critical analysis. While some commenters expressed frustration with AI art and the protest, others took a more lighthearted or philosophical approach to the topic.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • • The act of eating the AI art exhibit was compared to performance art and other provocative artistic gestures, such as the infamous banana at Art Basel.
  • • Commenters highlighted the growing tension between traditional and AI-driven artistic practices, reflecting broader societal debates about technology and creativity.
  • • Some pointed out the media's role in sensationalizing such incidents and fostering polarized opinions about AI.
  • 6. **Humorous Contributions**:
  • • Several commenters added humor to the discussion, with jokes about eating AI art and its "nutritional value" or comparing it to other absurd artistic protests.
  • 7. **Calls for Nuance**:
  • • A few commenters emphasized the need for a deeper understanding of AI tools and their capabilities, urging critics to move beyond surface-level judgments.

Others praised the use of AI but highlighted limitations, such as the inability to physically test products for ingredient accuracy or contamination. The project founder expressed aspirations to expand into lab testing and high-quality supplement production.
  • 2. **Regulatory Concerns**: Multiple commenters discussed the lack of oversight in the U.S. supplement industry, likening it to a "wild west." Issues like labeling inaccuracies and ingredient purity were raised, with suggestions that supplements should be regulated similarly to food. International comparisons (e.g., Australia) and niche concerns like pet food regulations were also mentioned.
  • 3. **Monetization Strategies**: Monetization was a recurring topic. The founder shared plans to rely on affiliate revenue rather than ads, citing affiliate commissions of 5-10%. Commenters encouraged exploring alternative models, referencing Examine.com as an example.   • 4. **Data Accuracy and Bugs**: Several comments identified data errors and site bugs, such as incorrect pricing and search issues. The founder acknowledged these issues and shared plans to prioritize fixes and improve data evaluations, especially for powdered supplements. They also expressed appreciation for feedback and the importance of building a community for ongoing improvement.
  • 5. **Sentiment Toward Supplements**: Commenters expressed mixed views on supplements. While some highlighted their importance for hard-to-get nutrients like Vitamin K2 and magnesium, others warned about risks like toxicity and emphasized eating real food. The founder agreed that many supplement sales are driven by marketing rather than science, reinforcing their goal to make the process more evidence-based.

They expressed enthusiasm for building a community to guide the project’s development and shared contact information for further collaboration.
  • 7. **Legal and Market Challenges**: Concerns about legal threats from supplement companies were discussed, with commenters advising against removing products under pressure. The founder noted their improved ability to handle such challenges and highlighted the vast market size of supplements, aiming to carve a niche by offering comprehensive data and comparisons.
  • 8. **Unique Features and Suggestions**: Commenters appreciated innovative features like AI responses triggered by adding a “?” to searches. Suggestions included expanding the dataset to cover the EU market and refining search functionality to avoid misleading results.
  • Overall, the discussion was constructive, with a mix of technical insights, critiques, and suggestions for improvement. Sentiment ranged from optimism about the project's potential to skepticism about AI's role in the supplement industry. The founder demonstrated openness to feedback and a clear vision for future growth.

Article Summary:

  • • AI coding tools like Claude Code and Codex are revolutionizing software development by automating tasks, allowing users to quickly create features or projects. However, not all developers embrace this shift, as some value the process of coding and learning over just the end result.
  • • For product-focused developers, these tools are transformative, enabling faster iterations and results by acting as "managers" of AI systems. But for others, like the author, the joy lies in understanding and building systems, which AI automation can diminish.
  • • The discussion highlights the importance of aligning tools with personal goals. Tasks where the process matters, such as learning or skill-building, may require a hands-on approach, while AI tools can be reserved for automating less valued, repetitive tasks.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **General Sentiment and Themes**:
  • • The discussion revolves around the use of AI coding agents, such as Claude Code, and their impact on software development.
  • • Opinions are split between those who view AI tools as valuable assistants that enhance productivity and those who express concern about their implications for craftsmanship and understanding in coding.
  • • The overall sentiment is mixed, with many commenters acknowledging the utility of AI tools while expressing varying levels of skepticism or enthusiasm.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • • AI tools are effective for automating repetitive or tedious tasks, such as refactoring, improving test coverage, or handling boilerplate code.
  • • Many commenters value AI tools for augmenting their coding process, enabling faster iterations, exploring alternatives, and providing insights on unfamiliar concepts.
  • • There is consensus that AI tools are helpful for personal projects, learning, and speeding up development workflows, but their reliability and accuracy require careful human oversight.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • • Some commenters argue that reliance on AI tools diminishes the value of understanding and creating software, while others counter that these tools are merely a means to save time and focus on higher-level problem-solving.
  • • A few express concerns about AI-generated code introducing subtle bugs and liabilities, leading to frustration and increased debugging efforts.
  • • There is debate over whether using AI tools trivializes the craft of coding or simply shifts focus to different aspects of software development.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters liken the use of AI tools to the adoption of power tools in craftsmanship, emphasizing that the goals of automation and manual creation are not necessarily opposed.
  • • Some view AI coding agents as "coding buddies" that enhance learning and experimentation, while others compare them to tools that democratize programming by lowering barriers to entry.
  • • A recurring theme is the trade-off between time savings and maintaining deep engagement with the code, with some commenters advocating for balancing both aspects.
  • 5. **Concerns About Industry Impact**:
  • • A few commenters raise concerns about AI tools potentially reducing the need for developers or lowering the skill level required for software changes, leading to job insecurity.
  • • There is anxiety about the broader implications of AI tools on the software development profession, with some fearing a shift toward commoditization or factory-level production.
  • 6. **Notable Analogies and Comparisons**:
  • • AI coding tools are compared to other technologies that automate tasks people don’t value doing, such as cars for transportation or Python for simplifying programming.
  • • The debate is likened to discussions in other creative domains, such as music, where automation and craftsmanship coexist but sometimes lead to polarized opinions.
  • 7. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • While many commenters appreciate the practical benefits of AI tools, such as saving time and enabling faster iterations, there is a strong undercurrent of concern about losing the creative and intellectual engagement that comes with manual coding.
  • • The discussion reflects a balance between pragmatism and idealism, with individuals expressing diverse perspectives based on their personal experiences and values.

  • • Tools like Restish and oauth2c exemplify a "no-code" philosophy by interpreting OpenAPI specs and simplifying OAuth 2.0 flows, replacing dense scripts with streamlined shell commands for API interactions.
  • • Reverse-engineering workflows using LLMs, such as creating Python clients from HAR files, demonstrates the potential for adversarial interoperability, empowering users to automate services even without official APIs.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics Discussed**:
  • • Tools and approaches for interacting with remote MCP servers and APIs using CLI, FUSE, and Bash.
  • • The use of large language models (LLMs) with APIs, particularly leveraging OpenAPI specifications and curl commands.
  • • Authentication challenges when using agents and CLI tools, including security concerns around credentials.
  • • Development of platforms and registries for AI tools, such as tpmjs.com, which provides multiple interaction methods (CLI, MCP, REST) for agents.
  • • Debate over the advantages and trade-offs of CLI tools versus MCPs, focusing on composability, schema enforcement, and reliability.
  • 2. **Key Themes**:
  • • CLI tools are widely appreciated for their composability, discoverability, and compatibility with LLMs. Several commenters view them as a natural interface for agents due to their simplicity and universality.
  • • Authentication remains a recurring challenge, with suggestions for proxy layers and scoped API tokens to address security issues.
  • • Structured data (as enforced by MCPs) is highlighted as crucial for building reliable pipelines, while CLI tools are noted for their flexibility but potential brittleness in complex scenarios.
  • • The role of standards like OpenAPI and JSON Schema is emphasized in ensuring consistency and reliability in API interactions.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements**:
  • • Many commenters agree on the utility of CLI tools for interacting with agents and APIs, particularly for their composability and ease of use.
  • • There is a shared sentiment that authentication and credential management are critical areas needing improvement.
  • • The importance of structured data and schema enforcement for reliable pipelines is acknowledged by several participants.
  • 4. **Disagreements**:
  • • Some commenters debate whether CLI tools or MCPs are better suited for interacting with agents, with arguments about composability versus structured data and reliability.
  • • One commenter expresses skepticism about the practical utility of current AI tooling advancements, criticizing the focus on creating text files (.md) over real-world software.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion is largely constructive, with commenters sharing insights, tools, and approaches to improve agent and API interactions.
  • • There is some critical sentiment regarding the broader AI tooling ecosystem, particularly around the lack of impactful real-world applications.
  • 6. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Suggestions for using proxy layers to securely manage credentials and prevent direct access by agents.
  • • Innovative approaches like tpmjs.com, which offers multiple interaction modalities for agents and automates skill generation using LLMs.
  • • Observations on the natural compatibility of CLIs with LLMs due to their sequential nature and universality.
  • Overall, the discussion highlights practical challenges and solutions in the use of CLI tools, MCPs, and APIs for agents, with a focus on composability, security, and structured data.
The state of modern AI text to speech systems for screen reader users
• Article: https://stuff.interfree.ca/2026/01/05/ai-tts-for-screenreaders.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730346
• Score: 49
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Despite advancements in AI-driven text-to-speech (TTS) technology, blind screen reader users remain underserved due to their unique needs for speed, clarity, and efficiency over natural-sounding voices. Popular systems like Eloquence, last updated in 2003, are outdated and difficult to maintain.
  • • Modern AI TTS models, such as Supertonic and Kitten TTS, face critical issues like dependency bloat, inaccuracy, slow response times, and lack of customization, making them unsuitable for screen readers.
  • • The community faces significant challenges in modernizing TTS systems for blind users, with potential solutions requiring millions in funding and expertise in linguistics, signal processing, and programming. Advocates hope for increased awareness and collaboration to address these gaps.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion revolves around the limitations and challenges of modern AI-based text-to-speech (TTS) systems, particularly in the context of screen readers used by blind individuals.
  • 2. A key theme is the mismatch between the goals of AI TTS systems and the specific needs of screen reader users. Commenters noted that while AI voices aim to sound natural and human-like, blind users prioritize speed, accuracy, and predictability, which modern systems often fail to deliver.
  • 3. Several commenters expressed frustration with AI TTS models, citing issues such as skipping words, mispronouncing numbers, generating garbled speech artifacts, and slower response times compared to legacy systems like Eloquence and ESpeak. These older systems, though outdated, are still favored by many blind users due to their efficiency and reliability.
  • 4. Some commenters provided technical insights into the limitations of current models, suggesting that implementation choices and architectural issues may be contributing to the problems. For instance, one commenter argued that modern systems could be optimized by tweaking chunk sizes for streaming, though this was debated by others.
  • 5. There is a general sentiment of concern and pessimism regarding the future of screen reader technology. Commenters highlighted the lack of overlap between modern TTS research and the needs of blind users, as well as the dwindling support for legacy systems. One commenter estimated that modernizing the preferred TTS stack would require significant funding and expertise, which seems unlikely to materialize.
  • 6. Broader accessibility issues were raised, such as the lack of support for screen readers in Linux Wayland environments and the proprietary protocols introduced by GNOME, which further complicate adoption. This has led some users to consider switching to Windows despite reservations.
  • 7. A few commenters proposed potential solutions, such as reverse-engineering older systems like Eloquence, though others pointed out the technical complexity and legal barriers involved.
  • 8. The sentiment across the discussion was mixed but leaned toward skepticism and disappointment. While some commenters praised the advancements in AI TTS models for general use, many agreed that these systems are not yet suitable for screen reader users and fail to address their unique requirements.
  • 9. One insightful comment suggested that AI's potential lies beyond improving screen readers and could instead serve as a conversational assistant for blind users, offering a more interactive and task-oriented experience.
  • 10. Overall, the discussion highlighted the gap between technological innovation in AI TTS and practical accessibility needs, with a consensus that significant improvements are required before these systems can effectively replace legacy solutions for screen readers.

}

}

  }
}
@media (max-width: 750px) {

    left: 8px;
    top: 45px;
  }
}

NSFW prompting, no sir…).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Incidentally, among AI subreddits, grok stands atop the leaderboard for NSFW mention frequency, if that’s any indication of where the action lies.</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Well, we can’t really say that consumers are buying OnlyFans for the articles. But, as Jonathan Coopersmith most famously laid out, there is a long tradition of vice driving the leading edge of tech, especially video, including editing, distribution, and compression. From VHS to cable to online video, porn has been an early monetizer, paving the way for broader adoption.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" iOS apps in the app store.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">After basically zero growth for the past three years, new app releases surged 60% yoy in December (and 24% on a trailing twelve month basis).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">It’s starting to feel like 2008, when Apple first released the iPhone SDK (now called the iOS SDK). While it initially debuted with approximately 500 third-party apps, app downloads surpassed 1M in the first weekend (and reached ~1B by early 2009). More apps drew more eyeballs which drew more apps, all of which eventually unlocked hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue for app developers (and a multi-trillion dollar ecosystem that no one had ever heard of a decade prior).</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">AI is similarly opening up an entirely new surface area for value creation, and mobile is emerging as an early winner on the frontier.</p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Microsoft released an “AI Diffusion” map, demonstrating the share of the working age population using a generative AI application during the second half of 2025. While adoption is increasingly widespread, there is a clear regional divergence such that “adoption in the Global North grew nearly twice as fast as in the Global South.”</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Somewhat surprisingly, the UAE sits atop the leaderboard (followed closely by Singapore), with ~64% of the working age population adopting AI (at least once, during the measured period).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">The US, for its part, increased adoption by ~2 percentage points since the first half of the year, but actually slipped a spot in the rankings from 23rd to 24th (following a big jump by South Korea).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Microsoft points out that AI adoption is hard to measure, so this is really just one way of looking at the picture, but it’s striking nonetheless.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Adoption is increasing pretty much everywhere, with roughly the entirety of the OECD demonstrating at least 20% adoption. If the adoption gap continues to widen, though, one can only imagine that the second- and third-order effects of being an “AI have v. AI have-not” will be amplified.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size: 20px;">³</span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro combined ~$22B of inventory, the highest level in more than a decade (and an increasingly large share of total sales).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Remy Cointreau really breaks the scale with ~€1.8B in aging sprits that’s nearly double its annual revenues, and more than 80% of the company’s total market cap</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">No one knows precisely why alcohol sales have disappointed quite so much (and there probably isn’t one reason). Likewise, some part of the inventory build is the result of over-producing in response to a pandemic bump in sales (that turned out to be temporary).</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>That all being said, whether it’s GLP-1s, shifting consumer preferences (especially among younger folks), Chinese tariffs, and/or something else entirely, drinking as a global pastime has surely fallen off the wagon (at least for now).</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size: item.title: Claude Code Tasks 🤖, Google personal AI search 🔍, evals for skills 📝
item.description:
Anthropic has upgraded Todos in Claude Code to Tasks, a new primitive that helps Claude Code track and complete more complicated projects ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR AI 2026-01-23

Airia: Enterprise AI orchestration that unifies experimentation, prod, and governance (Sponsor)

You want AI to be more than a never-ending work in progress, and that means enabling no-code, low-code, and pro-code development without IT gatekeepers standing in the way. Yet that doesn't mean governance goes out the window.

Airia is the enterprise AI platform built to drive AI adoption by unifying innovation and security. Teams at Stryker, BuzzFeed, and ArcelorMittal use it to:

  • Test prompts, LLMs, and agent variants in safe, prod-like environments 
  • End AI anxiety by controlling agent sprawl and implementing automatic guardrails
  • Discover risks, orchestrate agents, and monitor threats in one place

Get a demo and make AI adoption a reality

🚀

Headlines & Launches

We're turning Todos into Tasks in Claude Code (2 minute read)

Anthropic has upgraded Todos in Claude Code to Tasks, a new primitive that helps Claude Code track and complete more complicated projects and collaborate on them across multiple sessions or subagents. Claude can create Tasks with dependencies on each other that are stored in the metadata, mirroring how projects work. Tasks are stored in the file system so that multiple subagents or sessions can collaborate on them. Updates are broadcasted to all sessions currently working on the same Task List when one session updates a Task.
Personalized Search with AI Mode (4 minute read)

Google is expanding "Personal Intelligence" in Search, enabling AI Mode to use private context from Gmail and Photos for more personalized results.
🧠

Deep Dives & Analysis

Pantera Blockchain Letter :: January 2026 (25 minute read)

Macro, positioning, flows, and market structure effects were the dominant drivers last year, particularly for assets outside of Bitcoin. It was a difficult year for much of the token market, but the year also saw advanced institutional adoption, clarified product-market fit, and compressed valuations across large segments of the ecosystem. A strong fundamental backdrop following a year-long bear market for the broader token universe could present an opportunity. Forward-looking setups appear increasingly asymmetric, provided fundamentals stabilize and breadth returns.
Overcoming Compute and Memory Bottlenecks with FlashAttention-4 on NVIDIA Blackwell (7 minute read)

FlashAttention is an input/output aware algorithm that computes the same mathematical result as standard attention, but more efficiently. It uses reduced memory access and near-linear memory to achieve this. These optimizations lead to faster training and inference and enable models to handle longer sequences of tokens. FlashAttention-4, the latest iteration of optimized CUDA kernels, achieves a peak performance of 1,605 TFLOPS/s.
Building Deep Agent Frontends (38 minute read)

CopilotKit published a tutorial on building a fullstack Deep Agent app that includes resume ingestion, skill extraction, sub-agents with web search, and a streaming UI.
🧑‍💻

Engineering & Research

Design, build, and publish your site in hours on Framer — free for the first year (Sponsor)

Get from idea to live site in record time when you launch on Framer. Hundreds of YC-backed founders have already designed and published beautiful sites without dev resources. Now pre-seed and seed-stage startups get their first year free. Make your website the easy part of your startup and claim your free year
Qwen3-TTS Family is Now Open Sourced: Voice Design, Clone, and Generation! (35 minute read)

Qwen3-TTS is a series of speech generation models that supports voice cloning, voice design, ultra-high-quality human-like speech generation, and natural language-based voice control. The models support 10 mainstream languages (Chinese, English, Japanese, Korean, German, French, Russian, Portuguese, Spanish, and Italian) along with various dialects. They exhibit strong contextual understanding, allowing them to adapt tone, rhythm, and emotional expression based on instructions and text semantics.
Small models, big results: Achieving superior intent extraction through decomposition (6 minute read)

For agents to be truly helpful, the underlying models need to be able to understand what users are trying to do when they are interacting with them. Large multimodal LLMs are already good at understanding user intent, but this typically involves sending information to a server, which can be slow, costly, and carries the potential risk of exposing sensitive information. The task can be made more tractable for small models by separating user intent understanding into two stages.
D4RT: Unified, Fast 4D Scene Reconstruction & Tracking (3 minute read)

D4RT is a unified AI model for efficient 4D scene reconstruction and tracking that achieves up to 300x efficiency over traditional methods. Utilizing a unified encoder-decoder Transformer architecture, D4RT processes scenes dynamically by answering targeted queries about 3D space and time from 2D video inputs. This speed and scalability suit applications in robotics and augmented reality.
Robotics Video Benchmark and Dataset (GitHub Repo)

RBench is a benchmark for robotics video generation, and RoVid-X is a million-scale dataset for training embodied video models.
Render-of-Thought: Visualizing Reasoning Chains (18 minute read)

Render-of-Thought (RoT) converts reasoning steps into visual representations using VLMs, offering a more compact and analyzable alternative to Chain-of-Thought prompting. The method achieves better token compression and faster inference while maintaining competitive reasoning performance.
🎁

Miscellaneous

Salesforce Adopts Cursor at Scale (3 minute read)

Over 90% of Salesforce's 20,000 engineers now use Cursor in daily workflows, improving development speed and code quality. The shift has helped power product releases like Agentforce and signals broader industry trends in AI-assisted software engineering.
Thoughts on Evals (11 minute read)

Raindrop's AI monitors agents by generating billions of labels monthly, detecting issues, and providing performance insights in the real world. Unlike Eval Driven Development, Raindrop focuses on monitoring after deployment, allowing real-world feedback and faster iteration. Monitoring tools are more effective for AI products due to their dynamic nature, offering comprehensive real-world performance insights that static evals can't match.
⚡

Quick Links

TLDR is hiring a Senior Software Engineer, Applied AI ($200k-$300k, Fully Remote)

As the first engineer on TLDR's new Applied AI team, you'll build AI agents and composable Claude Skills to let non-technical teammates create their own AI workflows. Learn more.
Most people's mental model of Claude Code is that "it's just a TUI" (1 minute read)

Claude Code is closer to a small game engine.
Supply-chain risk of agentic AI - infecting infrastructures via skill worms (2 minute read)

Skills added to AI assistants can introduce significant security risks by executing shell, network, and filesystem commands.
Securing Agents in Production (11 minute read)

This post examines how Palantir's AIP Agentic Runtime secures agents across the full operational life cycle.
Inference startup Inferact lands $150M to commercialize vLLM (1 minute read)

Inferact, the creator of an open source vLLM project, has raised $150 million in seed funding at an $800 million valuation in a round co-led by Andreessen Horowitz and Lightspeed Venture Partners.

item.title: How Meta Is Reshaping Its Organization for an AI Computing Blitz
item.description:
How Meta Is Reshaping Its Organization for an AI Computing Blitz
Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg has expanded his direct reports to include the two co-heads of the company’s newly created Meta Compute team, signaling the importance of the new effort to manage Meta’s AI computing capacity needs. Zuckerberg announced Meta Compute in mid-January, declaring it a new “top-level initiative” that will be central to its plans to build hundreds of gigawatts’ worth of AI computing capacity over time. As reflected in our updated Meta org chart, the two co-heads of Meta Compute—Santosh Janardhan, head of global infrastructure, and Daniel Gross, vice president of product—now report directly to Zuckerberg. In total, our new Meta org chart shows 167 senior leaders at Meta, up from 148 in our previous org chart. (We’ve also updated a separate org chart for Meta Superintelligence Labs.)
Jan 23, 2026

Org Charts

How Meta Is Reshaping Its Organization for an AI Computing Blitz

By Jyoti Mann

Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg has expanded his direct reports to include the two co-heads of the company’s newly created Meta Compute team, signaling the importance of the new effort to manage Meta’s AI computing capacity needs.

Zuckerberg announced Meta Compute in mid-January, declaring it a new “top-level initiative” that will be central to its plans to build hundreds of gigawatts’ worth of AI computing capacity over time. As reflected in our updated Meta org chart, the two co-heads of Meta Compute—Santosh Janardhan, head of global infrastructure, and Daniel Gross, vice president of product—now report directly to Zuckerberg.

In total, our new Meta org chart shows 167 senior leaders at Meta, up from 148 in our previous org chart. (We’ve also updated a separate org chart for Meta Superintelligence Labs.)

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Mark Zuckerberg has expanded his direct reports to include Meta Compute’s leaders.
  • Meta Compute seeks talent for a commodities-like trading desk approach.
  • Our new org chart shows the 167 top leaders at Meta, up from 148 in our previous org chart.

item.title: Market share myths 🧠, selling to founders 🤝, power laws accelerate 📈
item.description:
Market share is a point estimate, not a scoreboard. When the iPhone launched in 2007, Apple's share was negligible next to Nokia and BlackBerry ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Founders 2026-01-23

Plaid adds $382k in pipeline with TLDR campaign (Sponsor)

Plaid achieved their best-performing direct buy to date, adding $382k in pipeline, earning 70 leads, and achieving 20.1x ROI. This case study breaks down their strategy, results, and example ads. Read the Plaid case study.
📈

Headlines & Trends

The Disequilibrium Advantage (6 minute read)

Startups face two clocks: burn rate and relevance as rapid change shortens runway impact. AI acts as a multiplier, shifting bottlenecks from execution to integration, distribution, and decision-making. Success hinges on building systems that address new constraints, prioritize trust, and focus on measurable outcomes rather than mere output.
Don't Confuse Market Share with Winning (4 minute read)

Market share is a point estimate, not a scoreboard. When the iPhone launched in 2007, Apple's share was negligible next to Nokia and BlackBerry. Today, Apple holds less than 25% of the global smartphone share. No one questions who's winning. DoorDash entered food delivery late, after Grubhub, Seamless, and Caviar. When Uber Eats tried to buy market share with heavy subsidies, DoorDash focused on building a logistics engine for suburban markets that competitors ignored. The pattern across Sequoia's portfolio is consistent: outliers don't chase market share. They build something that the market eventually moves toward.
🧠

Strategies & Tactics

Your problem framing is sabotaging your strategy (5 minute read)

Poor problem framing undermines strategic efforts in tech as companies focus on outputs over customer needs. The "build to learn" approach emphasizes technologies rather than understanding user problems, leading to misguided product metrics. Successful problem design requires collaboration, clear customer-driven objectives, and a focus on solutions that users value.
Pitch your fellow founder (5 minute read)

Founder-led podcasts, newsletters, and livestreams are the most underutilized channels for early-stage startups. These platforms care less about scale and more about perspective. One accounting software startup runs a weekly livestream where founders announce products, share funding news, and talk through what's actually working. The bar for getting on is different than traditional press. You need a news hook, a distinct point of view, or expertise other founders can apply. One AI startup got on with a launch, a three-month demo waitlist, and a yacht party. The pitch was a casual DM.
On Pricing, Pilots, and Early-Stage Enterprise Startups (5 minute read)

Early-stage enterprise AI founders should focus on the type of company they want to build rather than obsessing over specific pricing models. The key tradeoff is between high-volume growth versus high-price, low-volume niches, which shapes GTM strategy, sales motions, and churn risk. Design pilots deliberately with internal champions, scoped outcomes, and clear exit criteria, while pricing based on controllable factors like usage or memory to reduce surprises. Multiple tiers, add-ons, and explicit SLAs give startups leverage with enterprise buyers. Founders should be deliberate and flexible with pricing, as it directly impacts revenue trajectory, fundraising, and scaling speed.
⚒️

Tools & Resources

Reach real buyers in TLDR instead of fighting for attention on social (Sponsor)

TLDR puts you in front of your target audience with almost no competition. Each issue features only three advertisers max, giving your message the space it needs to stand out. Millions of developers, product managers, CEOs, and other tech decision makers actually see what you have to say. Learn more about running a test campaign.
Blink Agent Builder (Tool)

Blink Agent Builder is a vibe coding platform that creates AI agents capable of thinking, using tools, and completing tasks end-to-end from simple descriptions.
Fimo (Tool)

Fimo is a no-code AI-powered website builder that lets users create and evolve websites instantly.
Perfectly (Tool)

Fill startup roles with candidates 2x better, 4x faster.
🎁

Miscellaneous

Agency Is The Last Frontier (12 minute read)

Despite unprecedented access to knowledge, tools, and capital, most people fail to act and achieve meaningful outcomes. The limiting factor today is agency, the willingness to start, iterate, and learn by doing. High-agency people close the gap between what's possible and what actually happens. Capital, AI tools, and information are abundant, but action remains rare and is the key differentiator. Stop waiting and begin building now.
Vertical software already won the context graph (9 minute read)

Vertical software companies have been building context graphs, crucial for autonomous agents, by capturing specific business decisions for over a decade. Unlike horizontal platforms with broad, flexible data models, vertical software uses industry-specific ontologies to record reasoning and integrate functions, making decision traces more reconstructible. As AI and embedded services grow, vertical platforms hold a strategic advantage over horizontal SaaS and agent-first startups, with their deeply established context graphs.
⚡

Quick Links

AI Managing AI (3 minute read)

New startup opportunities have emerged in training the specialists that executives call first.
AI's Chicken Sandwich Problem (10 minute read)

A burger chain going all-in on chicken innovation and competition doesn't make sense unless it plans to transition to the chicken model.
Why Self-Made Generalists Will Shape the Next Big Thing (5 minute read)

Nad Chishtie, Head of Design at Lovable, illustrates the value of being a self-made generalist with expertise across design, coding, and systems thinking.
Blue Ocean SEO / AEO: Original thinking wins (3 minute read)

By the time users get to Google now, they've already asked ChatGPT the basic questions.

item.title: How ChatGPT scaled 📈, design engineering 🎨, making videos programmatically 🎥
item.description:
OpenAI scaled PostgreSQL to support 800 million ChatGPT users and millions of queries per second for its predominantly read-heavy workloads ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Dev 2026-01-23

Clerk MCP Server (Public Beta) (Sponsor)

The Clerk MCP server gives AI coding assistants direct access to current docs, patterns, and best practices. Prompt naturally, get accurate implementations.

Build prompts like:

  • "Set up a B2B SaaS with organizations and role-based permissions"
  • "Add Clerk middleware to my API"
  • "Build a waitlist with user metadata"

Try it today and share your feedback.

🧑‍💻

Articles & Tutorials

Scaling PostgreSQL to power 800 million ChatGPT users (14 minute read)

OpenAI scaled PostgreSQL to support 800 million ChatGPT users and millions of queries per second for its predominantly read-heavy workloads. To achieve this, its team offloaded write-heavy operations to sharded systems like Azure Cosmos DB and implemented application and query optimizations. Their architecture uses a single primary Azure PostgreSQL instance and nearly 50 global read replicas.
What is a Design Engineer? (5 minute read)

A design engineer bridges the gap between design and frontend development, creating software that not only works perfectly but also feels great to use. They directly implement designs in code, build and maintain design systems, and add in the critical final details of UI polish, like micro-interactions and animations.
Why does SSH send 100 packets per keystroke? (9 minute read)

A developer building a high-performance SSH game found that a single keystroke generated over 100 small packets. The root cause was identified as OpenSSH's keystroke timing obfuscation feature, which sends "chaff" packets to disguise typing patterns. By patching Go's SSH library to disable the `ping@openssh.com` extension server-side, the developer achieved a dramatic >50% reduction in CPU and bandwidth. LLMs assisted in the debugging process.
🧠

Opinions & Advice

Your App Subscription Is Now My Weekend Project (3 minute read)

This dev replaced his subscription apps, like Wispr Flow and Loom, by vibecoding his own personal alternatives. Despite having no prior macOS development experience, he quickly created custom applications that perfectly suited his specific needs for free. However, these apps are not production-ready, but rather perfect for personal projects.
My first year in sales as a technical founder (10 minute read)

A technical founder had a challenging but rewarding first year in sales. High-touch sales are vital for bootstrapped SaaS growth. Their best channel was their LinkedIn B2B sales funnel, with disciplined discovery calls.
🚀

Launches & Tools

Remotion Agent Skills (Website)

Remotion Agent Skills allow videos to be made programmatically with coding agents like Claude Code.
Townie's back in town! (3 minute read)

Townie v5 is an AI agent powered by Claude 4.5 designed to integrate directly into the browser alongside the code editor. The agent can perform nearly any action a user can, including managing code, files, versions, and databases, allowing for the rapid scaffolding of features or full-stack applications.
🎁

Miscellaneous

Keeping 20,000 GPUs healthy (11 minute read)

Modal runs a globally distributed pool of over 20,000 GPUs across multiple cloud providers. Its approach begins with instance type testing and selection, evaluating performance and reliability differences between cloud hyperscalers. This is followed by machine image preparation and automated boot checks to guarantee GPU health before customer workloads begin. Throughout an instance's life, Modal performs continuous passive and active healthchecking.
The Context Collapse Problem (11 minute read)

AI coding assistants deliver productivity gains on new projects but underperform on legacy codebases, a "context collapse problem" caused by the invisibility of institutional knowledge and historical decisions. Good solutions include treating documentation as infrastructure, incrementally restructuring code for AI legibility, and initially using senior engineers as "human context bridges.”
⚡

Quick Links

The best code is no code: composing APIs and CLIs in the era of LLMs (8 minute read)

LLMs should use composable shell commands and CLI tools, interpreting existing API standards or reverse-engineering them, to interact with services.
I was banned from Claude for scaffolding a CLAUDE.md file (6 minute read)

A Claude power user was banned without warning or explanation after using two Claude instances in a loop to scaffold a `CLAUDE.md` file containing system-like instructions, an activity they suspect triggered prompt injection detection.
CSS Optical Illusions (16 minute read)

This is a collection of over 50 optical illusions and interactive demos coded with CSS and HTML.
SSH has no Host header (3 minute read)

To route SSH connections to multiple VMs sharing IPv4 addresses, exe.dev assigns each VM a unique IP from a pool relative to its owner, then identifies the target VM using the incoming IP address and the user's public key, as SSH doesn't have a Host header equivalent.

item.title: 2025 Go Developer Survey 🦔, Rust 1.93 🆕, Bus Factor 🚌
item.description:
Go remains extremely well-liked, but developers want clearer best-practice guidance and better discoverability of high-quality modules ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR DevOps 2026-01-23

Get a free copy of the Forrester Wave for DevOps Platform: see why Atlassian is a leader (Sponsor)

Everyone recognizes DevOps as the modern standard, but is everyone actually integrating and automating development? That depends on their tooling AND their culture. 

The Forrester Wave DevOps Platforms report for Q2 2025 looks at what matters most in a modern DevOps platform. Read it free to see how the top 11 vendors compare on use cases such as:

  • Streamlining dev from idea to deployment with agentic AI
  • Improving software quality and engineering standards
  • Unifying incident, change, and release management to accelerate innovation

Access your complimentary copy

📱

News & Trends

Results from the 2025 Go Developer Survey (17 minute read)

Go remains extremely well-liked (91% satisfied), but developers want clearer best-practice guidance, better discoverability of high-quality modules, and improvements to core tooling like go command help. AI tools are widely used for learning and boilerplate, yet satisfaction is lukewarm due to code quality issues, while most Go work still centers on CLIs and APIs, with a noticeable pullback from AI features in production.
Announcing Rust 1.93.0 (2 minute read)

Rust 1.93.0 updates bundled musl to 1.2.5 for more reliable static Linux networking builds (with a long-prepared breaking change), allows Rust global allocators to safely use thread-local storage, and improves inline assembly with per-line cfg support. The release also stabilizes a large set of low-level and utility APIs (e.g., MaybeUninit, raw parts for String/Vec, unchecked integer ops, slice-to-array helpers, and formatting helpers) alongside standard Cargo and Clippy updates.
🚀

Opinions & Tutorials

CloudBees CEO: Why Migration Is a Mirage Costing You Millions (3 minute read)

A CloudBees survey found enterprises overspend on migration with frequent overruns, arguing modernization is wrongly equated with migration, which drains budgets and morale, undervalues resilient legacy systems, and diverts teams from delivering customer value.
How We Scaled Code Repository Management at DNSimple (9 minute read)

DNSimple automated GitHub repository management by replacing manual scripts with Terraform-based IaC, using CI/CD workflows and Terraform Cloud to enforce consistent settings, templates, permissions, and ownership with full visibility, code review, and scalable bulk updates.
How Binary Dependencies Work Across Different Languages (13 minute read)

Precompiled binary libraries can be called from higher-level languages through three main approaches: dynamic linking, dynamic loading via FFI, and dynamic linking using extension modules. These techniques differ in when symbol resolution happens and how data is converted, with extension modules offering the best performance and flexibility at the cost of more complex native code.
🧑‍💻

Resources & Tools

A zero-stress migration guide to help you 2x performance when replacing Ingress NGINX (Sponsor)

Don't just replace Ingress NGINX: upgrade to HAProxy for double the performance. HAProxy offers zero routing errors and a seamless path from Ingress to Gateway API. Launch the Migration Assistant to prepare for Ingress NGINX EOL in March on HAProxy's Ingress resource hub.
Vibe-Kanban (GitHub Repo)

Vibe Kanban is a workflow tool designed for an agent-driven development world. It helps engineers plan, coordinate, and review work done by AI coding agents rather than writing most code themselves. The tool centralizes agent configuration, supports parallel and sequential agent execution, enables fast review and dev server startup, and tracks task status across local or remote (SSH) projects.
NanoLang (GitHub Repo)

NanoLang is a minimal, LLM-friendly programming language with mandatory testing and unambiguous syntax. It transpiles to C for native performance while providing a clean, modern syntax optimized for both human readability and AI code generation.
🎁

Miscellaneous

How GEICO lowered its $300M cloud spend and decoupled security from the network (5 minute read)

GEICO cut its $300M cloud spend and improved reliability by shifting from network-centric security to identity-based controls, standardizing secrets with HashiCorp Vault, simplifying infrastructure, boosting portability, and building a scalable foundation for AI-driven modernization.
The Bus Factor (6 minute read)

A 2016 bus-factor analysis was rerun on major open-source repositories using 2024 data, showing most projects haven't improved knowledge distribution, with some (like Linux) declining sharply. Surprising results from GitHub Linguist filtering reveal weaknesses in authorship-only metrics and point to the need for richer signals like reviews and shared ownership.
Compiling Scheme to WebAssembly (5 minute read)

The Bob Scheme project was extended with a new compiler that lowers full Scheme directly to WebAssembly, using the WASM GC extension to support closures, cons cells, symbols, and garbage collection. The work highlights practical design choices—GC-managed structs, unboxed integers, manual string handling in linear memory, and core builtins like write implemented in raw WASM text—showing how a real high-level language can target WASM.
⚡

Quick Links

Code Orange: Fail Small — our resilience plan following recent incidents (7 minute read)

Cloudflare outlines Code Orange Fail Small, a top priority resilience plan created after November and December 2025 outages.
Building Resilient Applications with Layered Security (2 minute read)

Fastly launched new modular security packages with simpler, predictable pricing.

item.title: IG Reels ads soar 💸, canceled order winback 🛒, anti-engagement creators 🤔
item.description:
Over half of Instagram ads ran on Reels last year. Reels accounted for 46% of time spent on Instagram. Advertisers are following users ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR Marketing 2026-01-23

Is peace of mind one of your KPIs? Asana can help (Sponsor)

🤯 Despite everyone's best intentions, marketing campaigns can run perilously off-track. With all the stakeholders, review cycles, assets, and deadlines to juggle, something always gets lost in the confusion. 

😇 Here's where Asana comes in: Asana is the work management platform that unites marketers around common goals. In fact, IDC found that Asana boosts marketing teams' productivity by an average of 22%. 

🏃 So if this is the year you want your campaigns to launch faster (and with less chaos), then get your team a single source of truth with Asana. 

👉 Try Asana for free

📱

News & Trends

Most of Instagram's ads ran on Reels in 2025 (4 minute read)

Over half of Instagram ads ran on Reels last year. Reels accounted for 46% of time spent on Instagram. Advertisers are following users to short-form video, even as monetization lags behind the main feed. Amid competition with TikTok and YouTube Shorts, Reels drives user retention and a $50B annual run rate across Meta's platforms.
The Year of the Great Fracture (6 minute read)

2026 is shaping up as a year of fracture, where the “middle” has collapsed. The average customer no longer exists. Markets are splitting into clear extremes with different needs, resources, and behaviors. AI is commoditizing speed and efficiency, making trust the only real moat. Influence is moving from public platforms to private, owned channels. The winners are decisive operators who pick a side and act while others keep hedging.
🚀

Strategies & Tactics

E-commerce tip: Win back lost customers after cancelled orders (1 minute read)

After a customer has refunded or cancelled an order, send a survey email asking for the reason. Provide the most common answers that are simple to decide between, and use links to collect the response. Once the user clicks a link, save that option under their profile. From that, create a Cancelled/Refunded Order Winback Flow with personalized emails based on the survey answer they selected.
How to generate an extra $1M from retention (2 minute read)

Focus on fixing what is already broken instead of sending more campaigns. Identify where customers drop off, which products drive churn, and what delivery or support issues create friction. Lock in core flows like welcome, post-purchase, abandoned cart, replenishment, and winback before increasing broadcasts. Simplify segmentation and sharpen messaging so value is clear. Use post-purchase email to reduce regret and set expectations. Maintain a tight learning loop where every send drives a clear decision.
How Modern Animal got 50M views in three months (7 minute read)

Instead of educational or polished brand content, Modern Animal shifted to filming veterinarians mic'd up during real appointments, capturing candid conversations and behavior that viewers normally never see in veterinary clinics. Led by a two-person creative and social team, the strategy relied on multi-angle footage and minimal editorial framing, which helped a single post break out to 25M+ views and accelerate follower growth. The visibility translated into higher site traffic during viral periods and increased comfort among potential customers who said the content reduced anxiety about what happens when pets go “in the back”.
🧑‍💻

Resources & Tools

How leaders at Airbnb, Microsoft, and Skyscanner are restructuring their creative teams (Sponsor)

Superside interviewed creative and marketing leaders at industry-leading brands like Airbnb and Microsoft to see how they prevent AI slop, set realistic expectations, and build thoughtful AI workflows. Hint: the problem often isn't a lack of ideas. Learn how to use AI as a force multiplier.
YouTube Distribution Is Tilting Toward Shorts, Pressuring Long-Form Reach, Data Suggests (3 minute read)

YouTube distribution is shifting toward Shorts, which is cutting long-form reach for many creators. Analysis of more than 500 channels shows average long-form views fell from about 150,000 to about 60,000 per upload, and the top 100 YouTubers saw a roughly 50% view drop in one week. Homepage space for long-form videos shrank from about ten slots in 2024 to two or three in 2025, while Shorts visibility from homepage and search roughly doubled versus 2024. Older Shorts now lose promotion after about 30 days, and AI-generated channels add pressure by capturing 63 billion views and an estimated $117 million in annual revenue. These shifts concentrate long-form views among fewer channels and raise sustainability risks since Shorts earn less revenue and require higher output.
7 Infographics for Your 2026 Marketing Strategy (3 minute read)

This post introduces 7 infographics that translate common 2026 marketing challenges into execution frameworks, including system-based planning, integrated inbound-outbound motion, and content mapped to how buyers actually progress. It highlights practical shifts such as broadening audience scope without chasing empty reach and prioritizing existing customers as a growth lever through offer expansion and pricing strategy. None of these approaches work without an annual review of marketing foundations, where fresh customer research directly informs positioning decisions and budget allocation.
🎁

Miscellaneous

Anti-engagement (4 minute read)

A new generation of creators is redefining influence by embracing mystery instead of full transparency. They use anti-engagement strategies like erratic posting, faceless profiles, and selective disclosure. This makes audiences actively seek them out. Followers form devoted, idea-driven communities rather than casual fans. Influence is based on a worldview or aura, not lifestyle visibility. By resisting algorithms and controlling access, these creators make their presence compelling through what is withheld.
GenAI, The Snake Eating Its Own Tail (11 minute read)

AI weakens the ecosystems it relies on. Models trained on human content extract value without attribution or revenue for creators. This accelerates the decline of open source and publishing. The result is a broken incentive loop that risks a long-term content collapse. A proposed fix is pay-per-use AI, with source citations and revenue sharing, so creators, users, and AI companies all benefit.
⚡

Quick Links

Simple App Growth Loop That Works (1 minute read)

Post UGC daily, track saves and comments, and turn the top 10% into ads.
YouTube will soon let creators make Shorts with their own AI likeness (2 minute read)

YouTube is adding creator-controlled likeness features alongside generative clips, stickers, auto-dubbing, and new safeguards that let creators remove unauthorized AI-generated uses of their face or voice.
The gentlemen's agreement that netted 210,000 subscribers (4 minute read)

My First Million replaced the standard “like and subscribe” prompts with a recurring bit called the Gentlemen's Agreement, which framed subscribing as a humorous mutual contract after a listener's first episode.

SECURITY

ICE Agents Are ‘Doxing’ Themselves

BY MADDY VARNER | 4-MINUTE READ

The alleged risks of being publicly identified have not stopped DHS  and ICE employees from creating profiles on LinkedIn, even as Kristi Noem threatens to treat revealing agents' identities as a crime.

 
 

BUSINESS

Elon Musk Sure Made Lots of Predictions at Davos

BY AARIAN MARSHALL | 3-MINUTE READ

Humanoid robots, space travel, the science of aging—Musk weighed in on all of it at this week’s World Economic Forum. But his predictions rarely work out the way he says they will.

 
 

POLITICS

AI-Powered Disinformation Swarms Are Coming for Democracy

BY DAVID GILBERT | 4-MINUTE READ

Advances in artificial intelligence are creating a perfect storm for those seeking to spread disinformation at unprecedented speed and scale. And it’s virtually impossible to detect.

 
 

BUSINESS

How Claude Code Is Reshaping Software—and Anthropic

BY MAXWELL ZEFF | 6-MINUTE READ

WIRED spoke with Boris Cherny, head of Claude Code, about how the viral coding tool is changing the way Anthropic works.

ADVERTISEMENT

 
 

SECURITY

149 Million Usernames and Passwords Exposed by Unsecured Database

BY LILY HAY NEWMAN | 2-MINUTE READ

This “dream wish list for criminals” includes millions of Gmail, Facebook, banking logins, and more. The researcher who discovered it suspects they were collected using infostealing malware.

 

IN CASE YOU MISSED IT

Chinese EV Batteries Are Eating the World

BY ZEYI YANG | 3-MINUTE READ

China’s lithium batteries aren’t always “made in China.” Companies like BYD and CATL are building factories on nearly every continent.

CULTURE

Sorry MAGA, Turns Out People Still Like ‘Woke’ Art

BY MANISHA KRISHNAN | 3-MINUTE READ

From Black vampires gobbling up Oscar nominations to gay pro hockey players dominating the culture, diverse stories broke through in an environment that’s increasingly hostile to them.

 
 

GEAR

Legislators Push to Make Companies Tell Customers When Their Products Will Die

BY BOONE ASHWORTH | 3-MINUTE READ

A pair of bills in Massachusetts would require manufacturers to tell consumers when their connected gadgets are going dark. It should be a boon for cybersecurity as connected devices grow obsolete.

 
 

DEAL OF THE DAY

One of Our Favorite Smart Plugs for Apple Users Is $15 Off

BY BRAD BOURQUE | 1-MINUTE READ

The Meross Smart Plug Mini boasts excellent compatibility and slim construction.
